story:
Story:

Delilah is a young and beautiful woman, who after years of living a tough life in England, has found herself in a seemingly comfortable lifestyle besides her partner,  a drug dealer named Arthur Colbbs. But behind all the love and luxury, Delilah is stuck in a relationship full of abuse and darkness, subjecting herself to beatings, and surrounded by the dirty and disturbing reality of the crime world.

The film follows her inner journey in search for the self value and courage needed to break away from the abuse and from the life of crime, as she questions how far she should go for the love she thinks she deserves and feels. 

Director's Statement:

- 

“My Dear Delilah” is, above all, a very personal piece. During the creation process, this project took a very heavy toll on me - both physically and emotionally - as I searched for the most accurate tone and truthful way to express what it means to suffer from love, and the agony surrounding the reality of abusive relationships. 

Inspired by classic Noir, this film strives to bring very real events, into an almost surreal reality, atemporal and dramatized into what is a world of it’s own. Crime, abuse, despair, revenge, and search for freedom, all thrown into a time capsule with the look of the 20s, setting of the 80s and freshness of modern days. This is the story of the becoming of a femme-fatale, but more than that, is Delilah’s journey towards self-worth, and all that has to be sacrificed on her hard path. 

I hope I can shine a light into what, unfortunately, is a reality for many women, and make others take into consideration how many moments of quiet pain and suffering have been involved in the shaping of their life stories. I hope, also, that it will be an enjoyable film, and that the emotions come through to the watcher, as purely as possible. 

- Julia Basques

What You Should Know:

This short film is being produced with the intention of entering national and international Film Festival circuits. After gathering all my personal funds to put into this project, I am requesting your help in funding so that I can bring it to it's fullest potential. This very stylized piece brings to action a decade-play, mixing elements of the roaring 20s, the crime and drug-filled 80s, and the freshness of modern days, to represent the atemporality of the subject in discussion. 

Produced at the New York Film Academy, the production has been provided with a RED Scarlet package, basic sound gear and a Lighting Kit. Locations and all cast and crew have been locked down and accommodated into my personal funds for the budget.

All gathered  funding will be placed towards production design and technicals such as lighting and sound gear, and post-production work (professional sound mixing and designing & professional color correction).

For the full Producer Package, and more specific breakdowns in budgeting, please contact  baskoirfilms@gmail.com.

 

Cast and Crew:

Julia Basques - Writer/Director; Producer

Julia Basques is a passionate filmmaker, currently studying for her Bachelors in Fine Arts degree at the New York Film Academy - South Beach. Born and raised in Belo Horizonte, Brazil, Julia has always been in love with film and all forms of art. 

Founder of BASKOIR Films, Julia is just now launching her career. She believes that all art is personal and should be expressed as genuinely as possible, which is why, with BASKOIR, she strives to share not only her perspective, but also collaborate with a team of artists to gather a variety of views, ideas and experiences to extract all that is raw and real, in order to become a true storyteller.

With an eye for light and an interest in darkness, there is always an intriguing tone of contrast in her work. ​

"I want to show my perspective, share my voice, and use all my skills to be a true storyteller."

Previous Work:

Writer/Director: "Lovely Lonely High" https://vimeo.com/juliabasques/lovelylonelyhigh

Cinematographer/Producer: "The Gunman" https://vimeo.com/316477763

Director/Cinematographer: "Since I've Been Loving You - Montage" https://vimeo.com/263544946

 

Thorn Daniels - Producer and 1st Assistant Director

Thorn Daniels is a Filmmaker From York County, Pennsylvania, who currently resides in Miami and studies for his Masters degree in Film. When not making movies - or fighting crime - he can be found on South  Beach at 7/11 eating a hot dog.

Thorn is the founder of Spin-Off Boi Productions, an up-and-coming film production company, working in association with BASKOIR Films for the third time, after co-producing the short films "Lovely, Lonely High" and "The Gunman".

Previous work:

Writer/Director & Producer: "The Gunman" https://vimeo.com/316477763

Writer/Director: "Zippo" https://vimeo.com/316620953

 

Carlos Arroyo - Director of Photography

Hello, my name is Carlos Arroyo, I'm a filmmaker and I also attend the New York Film Academy. "My Dear Delilah" will be 13th film which I shoot, and I cannot say enough about how ecstatic I am to be a part of it, let alone shoot it.

I'm really going into the pre-production process so I could really dig in and accomplish everything that Julia and I want to do in this production. This will be the second film I shoot for Julia, the first one being "Lovely, Lonely High".

I cannot wait for the people to see this film.

 

Tatiana Grudinina - Lead Actress (Delilah)

Locations and all cast and crew have been locked down and accommodated into my personal funds for the budget.All gathered  funding will be placed towards production design and technicals such as lighting and sound gear, and post-production work (professional sound mixing and designing & professional color correction).For the full Producer Package, and more specific breakdowns in budgeting, please contact  baskoirfilms@gmail.com. Cast and Crew:Julia Basques - Writer/Director; ProducerJulia Basques is a passionate filmmaker, currently studying for her Bachelors in Fine Arts degree at the New York Film Academy - South Beach. Born and raised in Belo Horizonte, Brazil, Julia has always been in love with film and all forms of art. Founder of BASKOIR Films, Julia is just now launching her career. She believes that all art is personal and should be expressed as genuinely as possible, which is why, with BASKOIR, she strives to share not only her perspective, but also collaborate with a team of artists to gather a variety of views, ideas and experiences to extract all that is raw and real, in order to become a true storyteller.With an eye for light and an interest in darkness, there is always an intriguing tone of contrast in her work. ​"I want to show my perspective, share my voice, and use all my skills to be a true storyteller."Previous Work:Writer/Director: "Lovely Lonely High" https://vimeo.com/juliabasques/lovelylonelyhighCinematographer/Producer: "The Gunman" https://vimeo.com/316477763Director/Cinematographer: "Since I've Been Loving You - Montage" https://vimeo.com/263544946 Thorn Daniels - Producer and 1st Assistant Director
Thorn Daniels is a Filmmaker From York County, Pennsylvania, who currently resides in Miami and studies for his Masters degree in Film. When not making movies - or fighting crime - he can be found on South  Beach at 7/11 eating a hot dog.Thorn is the founder of Spin-Off Boi Productions, an up-and-coming film production company, working in association with BASKOIR Films for the third time, after co-producing the short films "Lovely, Lonely High" and "The Gunman".Previous work:Writer/Director & Producer: "The Gunman" https://vimeo.com/316477763Writer/Director: "Zippo" https://vimeo.com/316620953 Carlos Arroyo - Director of PhotographyHello, my name is Carlos Arroyo, I'm a filmmaker and I also attend the New York Film Academy. "My Dear Delilah" will be 13th film which I shoot, and I cannot say enough about how ecstatic I am to be a part of it, let alone shoot it.I'm really going into the pre-production process so I could really dig in and accomplish everything that Julia and I want to do in this production. This will be the second film I shoot for Julia, the first one being "Lovely, Lonely High".I cannot wait for the people to see this film. Tatiana Grudinina - Lead Actress (Delilah)

story:
The Director

Jordan Nunn is an undergraduate film student at San Francisco University. Ever since she was little she's had a  passion for horror films. She was inspired to make this film by seeing many unrealistic expectations of women body types portrayed on social media. She is hoping that many young women will think twice about what they are seeing and how it can effect them. 

  • This campaign is essential to making this film come to life. Since this is a serious issue we want to make this film as realistic and high quality as possible. 
  • By supporting this film you will be helping Jordan bring awareness to young adults about unrealistic expectations that are portrayed by social media influencers and the effects it can have on self image. 

How you are supporting us

  • TALENT- We are paying our actress for her performance!
  • SFX- This production features intensive SFX and it is important to us that is looks as realistic as possible!
  • Location- To portray authenticity.
  • Props and Costumes- To accurately portray the social media models!
  • Gear and equipment- While SFSU has many different resources we will need to look outside of SFSU for certain equipment needed to make the film as high quality as possible!
  • Set design - To create a visually pleasing image and to portray visual poetry.

The Impact

Any donation is greatly appreciated ! No donation is too small for student filmmakers!

  • Unrealistic expectations about an ideal women body type has been discussed through the lenses of magizines being unrealistic. However, it hasn't been explored through the lenses of social media. 
  • Jordan has worked on many professional film sets in L.A through out high school, has won film competitions, and has worked on many different student films while attending SFSU. She also was involved in broadcast journalism and edited 2 documentaries. 
  • Jordan has a deep love and passion for horror films and bringing awareness to issues that aren't usually spoken about. This film accomplishes both thus why it is so close to her heart!

story:
Two young men, on opposite sides, meet on the battlefield in Iraq; but this could be any battlefield.  Had they met anywhere else they might have been friends, but this is Fallujah.  This film is intended to educate the public on the cruelty, the brutality and the fog of war while also showing the human side and the bonds that tie all of us together.

This film is dedicated to all veterans, on all sides, of all wars.  See you on the other side.
story_txt:

This film is dedicated to all veterans, on all sides, of all wars.  See you on the other side.

story:
Short Summary

"Money or God," tells the story of two friends JJ and Benji, on two different journeys in life. JJ's job doesn't pay him enough so he can't stop selling drugs on the side. Benji needs to keep his job as he has saved nearly enough for his daughter's liver operation. Benji's money goes missing. JJ offers him a share in a drug deal, Benji refuses and advises him to change his ways and turn to God but instead, JJ ends up in the crossfire of a drug feud.  
Kofi, the writer/producer is passionate about storytelling which delves into themes of the gospel, streetlife, social injustice and personal struggles. About to complete his Master's degree at Met Film School and eager to launch his career in the UK Film Industry, he used his own money to shoot a pilot of the web series and now he is asking for contributors to help him complete it. With an ambitious crew, he aspires to create a film that we can relate to and learn from.

Production still from the pilot.

Your contribution to the "Money or God" web series will allow Kofi and the team to bring together the resources necessary to make the web series an engaging one.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need £10,000 to fund the project. This budget will be used across pre-production, production, and post-production, aiding with compensation to cast and crew, location rentals, food, as well as VFX, music composition and securing music copyright.

Have a look at the breakdown below for more details:

Even if we do not reach our desired goal, all the money we raise will go into the production which we plan to shoot in Mid-October. We also offer a range of perks including end credits thank you list, postcards, t-shirts, associate producer credit, executive producer and more. Please check them out as listed at the side of the page!

The Impact

Money or God web series will show us how the choices that we make in life are sometimes, only between 2 things, money and God.

A NOTE FROM THE PRODUCER

It all began with a quote from the bible I read in Luke 16:13 which taught me that, if we were to study the choices that we make in life carefully, we will reduce them into 2 things, money or God. So, in writing the script, I just looked into my own life experiences, and then scenarios that I have witnessed people make critical choices between money and God. 

Then, realizing that it's the bucket that's half full that everybody wants to help fill it to the brim, I used money from my savings to finance the pilot to see if this idea works. And thankfully, I am now glad to be able to call for your contributions to bring this project to life.

Your contribution is valuable to the project because it will help me pay actors and crew, location rentals and post-production cost. And it will help the world to see the bigger picture and think carefully about the choices that we make.

Also, with my MA Post-Production skills, I'm able to contribute to the editing, color grading, and sound design. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Other than contributing, please help us share this campaign and get the word out! 

Also, feel free to follow our social media handles @MONEYORGOD

Thanks for all the support!

story:
Imagine overcoming depression with 1 pill. 

 

This is the vision that got this documentary started.

 

In the more formal way of speaking, this is a documentary about several students setting up psychedelic clubs at the University College London, Harvard University, University of Pennsylvania, and Princeton University, promoting the study of psychedelics for mental health and consciousness research, and expanding into an intercollegiate network across a few countries. 

But I could also say, it is a one-year video journal of my friends and I’s journey on finding out how psychedelic drugs could help solve a few problems in our society: 

how can we more effectively cure a number of mental illnesses (depression, anxiety, PTSD, addiction),

better understand what consciousness is, and

alleviate human suffering?

 


 


~ THE STORY ~

 

My name is Wendi. I just finished my freshman year at Princeton, and have been taking a gap year since the fall of 2019 to pursue my artistic passions. It was on a subway ride in mid-August when it occurred to me that I would really like to make a feature-length documentary, about some of my friends. And I wanted to spend a whole year, or two, on it.

 

These are some of the weirdest people I have met. 

 

I remember meeting several of them for the first time at Princeton’s Envision Conference in December 2018. I’d had hours of mind-blowing conversations with these science majors about meditation, consciousness, literature, existential risks, society’s future.

Then, in a dinner circle, they said they were interested in psychedelics.

So unprepared to hear this, I secretly pulled out my phone and googled — yes, they are talking about drugs, hard drugs that produce hallucinations.


It turned out, most of these students—these newfound friends that I knew right away were going to change my life—had gone to really dark places mentally.

 

At various points not so long ago, they couldn’t find a justification to continue living.

One of them was sent to an eating disorder clinic for a few months.

Several of them engaged with serious suicidal thoughts.

Somewhere on their own paths of healing, they discovered psychedelics. Simply reading about psychedelics research on the internet served as a main source of hope for a long time. 

 

 

While pursuing medicine, neuroscience, or computer science, they went on establishing student clubs on psychedelics—compounds that have been heavily associated with the uncritical and unscientific hippie culture from the 1960s.

In the past few years, their journeys with the psychedelic clubs were filled with all sorts of emotional experiences:

being reluctantly bound to a hippie culture they don’t identify with,

failing to find an official faculty advisor after 10 of them expressed verbal support,

selling 1000 tickets in 10 minutes for the first public event, and,

losing a friend they started the club with as she took away her own life

 

 

In October 2019, they established the Intercollegiate Psychedelic Network (IPN), which, within the first 3 months, has grown to include almost 20 colleges from the US, UK, and Switzerland, with several more universities in the progress of setting up their own psychedelic clubs. 

The IPN is organizing the 2nd Intercollegiate Psychedelic Summit on April 17-20, 2020, on Harvard campus, almost 60 years after Timothy Leary and Richard Alpert got expelled from Harvard for their psychedelics research. 

Some of the confirmed speakers include:

a former President of the American Psychiatric Association (APA),

Psychiatrist-in-Chief of the Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH),

cofounder of the World Transhumanist Association, and

the Founder and Executive Director of the Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies. 

 

 

These students are passionate about psychedelics with a serious cause. The individuals this documentary focuses on are simply a few in the larger movement among colleges and the broader community in the West working on psychedelics research and decriminalization. 

 

I feel fortunate to have been introduced to psychedelics by my friends, to witness what they have been continuously achieving, and, now, to tell their stories.

​

 

~ BUDGET ~

 

The money this campaign raises will be used in 3 ways:

1. Equipment

$5928

  • Canon C100 + 1 zoom lens
    (this is one of the cheapest film cameras for professional productions. It's cheaper this way than renting the camera for the whole time. I have already paid out of my own pocket for the other necessary equipments)
  • rental of 1 camera for 1 more filmmaker for several days, to get more dynamic views for events

 

2. My personal travel expenses 

$2649

  • 5 US cities, 1.5 months
  • plane and bus tickets + food + splitting the time between youth hostels + crashing my friends' rooms

 

3. *****Funding a few subjects to take psychedelics for the film in Amsterdam!!*****

$6157  

  • 6 days
  • flights (from the east coast & China) + youth hostels + basic food & transport
  • 3-5 subjects of the film + me + 1 other filmmaker

 

Magic truffles (a type of psychedelics) are legal in Amsterdam. If we get enough money, I will fund a few subjects of the documentary to take magic truffles in front of the camera, so that the documentary shows the entire process of how some of the students featured in the film use psychedelics to heal and gain personal insights. 

This is perhaps the most important part of the documentary. A lot of people are scared or concerned about psychedelics because of how crazy and unfathomable psychedelic experiences could sound like. I believe that a huge part of legitimizing psychedelics has to come from visually showing what psychedelic experiences look like when they are induced with care and seriousness.

Given the current stigma, researchers most often can't talk about their personal use, which makes it a precious things that a few of the subjects of this film agreed to take psychedelics in front of the camera. 

 

 

Extra money raised will go into:

  1. leveling up the film's quality: music commission with other artists, VFX work
  2. outreach: festival submissions, traveling expenses for visiting organizations and individuals for further promotion work 

 


 

~ BACKGROUND ~

 

There is a "psychedelic renaissance."

We are inheriting a legacy from ancestors, including indigenous cultures that have used psychedelics from millennia, as well as the researchers of the 1900s. 

Now we must ask ourselves - what will our legacy in using these tools for healing and growth be?

 

While psychedelics are still classified as Schedule I (US) and Class A (UK) drugs--the same groups as heroin, more and more research has shown promising effects of psychedelics in treating a number of mental illnesses: depression, PTSD, anxiety in cancer patients, alcohol addiction, and more.

 

Imperial College London, Johns Hopkins University, and New York University have been three major universities in psychedelic research in the past few years.

Several cities in the US and a few other Western countries are decriminalizing psychedelics.

Famous podcasters Joe Rogan (7 million Youtube subscribers) and Tim Ferriss (often ranked #1 business podcast on all of Apple Podcasts) have both dedicated multiple episodes to a range of psychedelics. Tim Ferriss is also a major donor of the world's first two psychedelic research centers that opened in 2019. 

 

A little timeline of the very recent events:

 

June 2018 - Harvard journalism professor Michael Pollan published How to Change Your Mind, a book about the history of psychedelics and his own psychedelic experiences. The New York Times Book Review listed the book as one of the 10 best books of the year.

October 2018 - FDA granted psilocybin "Breakthrough Therapy" for Compass Pathways' psilocybin therapy for treatment-resistant depression

April 2019 - Imperial College London opened its Centre for Psychedelic Research -- first of its kind in the world

May 2019 - Denver (CO) became the 1st US city to decriminalize psilocybin mushrooms

June 2019 - Oakland (CA) became the 2nd US city to decriminalize psilocybin mushrooms, while also decriminalizing DMT, ibogaine, and mescaline

September 2019 - Johns Hopkins University opened its Center for Psychedelic & Consciousness Research, with $17 million in research funding

November 2019 - FDA granted psilocybin a "Breakthrough Therapy" status for treating depression for the second time in over a year

now - activists in California and Oregon are pushing for state-wide decriminalization and legalization, respectively, of psychedelics. Berkeley (CA), Chicago (IL), Columbia (MI), Dallas (TX), Portland (OR), Port Townsend (WA), and Santa Cruz (CA) see city-level decriminalization efforts.

(full timeline of psychedelics can be found here)

 

Ever since I picked up and devoured Michael Pollan's How to Change Your Mind right at the beginning of 2019, I felt compelled to learn more about psychedelics because of my long-time passion for mental health. And throughout 2019, I felt like I was witnessing history happen in front of my eyes. 

The friends I met in December 2018 went on to establish psychedelic clubs at Harvard in February, at Penn in April (where they organized the 1st Intercollegiate Psychedelic Summit), and at Princeton in October. Then in the fall I found out about UCL's psychedelic society and its beautiful story spanning the last 4 years, which brought tears to my eyes when I read the long message from its founder.

I could not imagine not having something documented seriously.

This documentary could seem quite ambitious for a fresh young filmmaker like me. But, imagine witnessing history happen around you, imagine you happen to be friends with the people who are part of this history, imagine you happen to be taking a gap year and you are deeply committed to art, who would resist at least trying to make the documentary happen? 

 

The past 4 months of developing this project were filled with excitement and hope, as well as doubt and fear. I can't believe I am releasing this campaign and sharing with more people about this project that's tremendously important to me. 

 

I'm excited to share my friends' stories with more people.

People who are frustrated by the current mental health system, in which medicine often doesn't work and therapy is costly and time-consuming.

People who are open to new possibilities of envisioning a more joyful future. 

 

Your support will mean a lot to me, to people in the film, and the hundreds more students, researchers and activists of psychedelics.

 

 



~ SCHEDULE ~

 

In the last 4 months, I have:

  • submitted a 22-page application to the Sundance Documentary Fund, in which I outlined everything from story structure, artistic vision, to line budget and marketing strategy. While the chance of getting the funding is slim, spending dozens of hours strategizing everything about this documentary gave me a solid understanding of what I am doing with the whole project,

  • assembled a crew at the University College London, to film the London part of the documentary. The team directory is listed in the people section at psychedelicclubdoc.com
     
  • interviewed, for 4 hours total, scholars in psychology, neuroscience, chemistry and philosophy. Among them are:
    • Robin Carhart-Harris, head of the world’s first psychedelic research center affiliated to a university, and
    • Karl Friston, one of the world’s most influential neuroscientists and whose papers have been cited for more than 230,000 times,
       
  • collected 18 hours of footage with the UCL psychedelic society and its founder and president, including events and personal interviews
     
  • pitched the documentary to everyone I could, including ~30 individuals working in psychedelics research/therapy at a meeting at Imperial College’s psychedelic research centre,
     
  • consulted and received generous guidance from an Emmy-winning filmmaker, founder of Raindance Film Festival, and a former BBC interviewer. 

 

I’m currently at home organizing the footage, running this campaign, and doing more preparation work for future filming.

At the end of January, I will be heading to the Sundance Film Festival to volunteer for 9 days, and hopefully get to chat about this documentary with as many people as I can!

 

Here is the rest of the production schedule: 

 

GENERAL FILMING

March-April, 2020   
San Francisco, Philadelphia, Princeton, New York City, Boston

  • interviews with students, researchers, professors & other relevant individuals
  • student club meetings (meditations, rituals, etc)
  • the 2nd Intercollegiate Psychedelic Summit at Harvard

June, 2020
Amsterdam

  • a few subjects taking psychedelics (magic truffle) in Amsterdam, including the preparation, the trip, and the integration

POST-PRODUCTION

June-August, 2020

  • Finish the fine cut by the start of September

OUTREACH

from September, 2020, onwards

  • Submit the film to major film festivals like Sundance, Hot Docs, Sheffield Doc/Fest, and IDFA
  • Organize screenings on college campuses and organizations related to mental health, psychedelics, harm reduction, and consciousness studies

 


 

 

~ LAST WORDS ~

 

To be honest, I have no idea how much interest in this film there exists. I would imagine that many of you would be quite skeptical.  


Maybe we are being dumb.


And ignorant. And delusional. And overly idealistic. In which case, this documentary could still be quite entertaining. 

 

If you put aside the value judgment of how right these students are in their belief in and pursuit of using psychedelic drugs to eliminate mental sufferings, this documentary will still serve as an intimate archive of a few young individuals trying, not without doubt, to tackle some of the hardest problems in our society.

We may leave it to time and history to judge, perhaps through continuous reframing, what these students have been doing :)

 

If you have any questions, please let me know at: me@wendiyan.com

$5928

Canon C100 + 1 zoom lens(this is one of the cheapest film cameras for professional productions. It's cheaper this way than renting the camera for the whole time. I have already paid out of my own pocket for the other necessary equipments)
rental of 1 camera for 1 more filmmaker for several days, to get more dynamic views for events

 
2. My personal travel expenses 
$2649

5 US cities, 1.5 months
plane and bus tickets + food + splitting the time between youth hostels + crashing my friends' rooms

 
3. *****Funding a few subjects to take psychedelics for the film in Amsterdam!!*****
$6157  

6 days
flights (from the east coast & China) + youth hostels + basic food & transport
3-5 subjects of the film + me + 1 other filmmaker

 
Magic truffles (a type of psychedelics) are legal in Amsterdam. If we get enough money, I will fund a few subjects of the documentary to take magic truffles in front of the camera, so that the documentary shows the entire process of how some of the students featured in the film use psychedelics to heal and gain personal insights. 
This is perhaps the most important part of the documentary. A lot of people are scared or concerned about psychedelics because of how crazy and unfathomable psychedelic experiences could sound like. I believe that a huge part of legitimizing psychedelics has to come from visually showing what psychedelic experiences look like when they are induced with care and seriousness.
Given the current stigma, researchers most often can't talk about their personal use, which makes it a precious things that a few of the subjects of this film agreed to take psychedelics in front of the camera. 
 
 
Extra money raised will go into:


leveling up the film's quality: music commission with other artists, VFX work

outreach: festival submissions, traveling expenses for visiting organizations and individuals for further promotion work 

 

 

~ BACKGROUND ~
 
There is a "psychedelic renaissance."
We are inheriting a legacy from ancestors, including indigenous cultures that have used psychedelics from millennia, as well as the researchers of the 1900s. 
Now we must ask ourselves - what will our legacy in using these tools for healing and growth be?
 
While psychedelics are still classified as Schedule I (US) and Class A (UK) drugs--the same groups as heroin, more and more research has shown promising effects of psychedelics in treating a number of mental illnesses: depression, PTSD, anxiety in cancer patients, alcohol addiction, and more.
 
Imperial College London, Johns Hopkins University, and New York University have been three major universities in psychedelic research in the past few years.
Several cities in the US and a few other Western countries are decriminalizing psychedelics.
Famous podcasters Joe Rogan (7 million Youtube subscribers) and Tim Ferriss (often ranked #1 business podcast on all of Apple Podcasts) have both dedicated multiple episodes to a range of psychedelics. Tim Ferriss is also a major donor of the world's first two psychedelic research centers that opened in 2019. 
 
A little timeline of the very recent events:
 
June 2018 - Harvard journalism professor Michael Pollan published How to Change Your Mind, a book about the history of psychedelics and his own psychedelic experiences. The New York Times Book Review listed the book as one of the 10 best books of the year.
October 2018 - FDA granted psilocybin "Breakthrough Therapy" for Compass Pathways' psilocybin therapy for treatment-resistant depression
April 2019 - Imperial College London opened its Centre for Psychedelic Research -- first of its kind in the world
May 2019 - Denver (CO) became the 1st US city to decriminalize psilocybin mushrooms
June 2019 - Oakland (CA) became the 2nd US city to decriminalize psilocybin mushrooms, while also decriminalizing DMT, ibogaine, and mescaline
September 2019 - Johns Hopkins University opened its Center for Psychedelic & Consciousness Research, with $17 million in research funding
November 2019 - FDA granted psilocybin a "Breakthrough Therapy" status for treating depression for the second time in over a year
now - activists in California and Oregon are pushing for state-wide decriminalization and legalization, respectively, of psychedelics. Berkeley (CA), Chicago (IL), Columbia (MI), Dallas (TX), Portland (OR), Port Townsend (WA), and Santa Cruz (CA) see city-level decriminalization efforts.
(full timeline of psychedelics can be found here)
 
Ever since I picked up and devoured Michael Pollan's How to Change Your Mind right at the beginning of 2019, I felt compelled to learn more about psychedelics because of my long-time passion for mental health. And throughout 2019, I felt like I was witnessing history happen in front of my eyes. 
The friends I met in December 2018 went on to establish psychedelic clubs at Harvard in February, at Penn in April (where they organized the 1st Intercollegiate Psychedelic Summit), and at Princeton in October. Then in the fall I found out about UCL's psychedelic society and its beautiful story spanning the last 4 years, which brought tears to my eyes when I read the long message from its founder.
I could not imagine not having something documented seriously.
This documentary could seem quite ambitious for a fresh young filmmaker like me. But, imagine witnessing history happen around you, imagine you happen to be friends with the people who are part of this history, imagine you happen to be taking a gap year and you are deeply committed to art, who would resist at least trying to make the documentary happen? 
 
The past 4 months of developing this project were filled with excitement and hope, as well as doubt and fear. I can't believe I am releasing this campaign and sharing with more people about this project that's tremendously important to me. 
 
I'm excited to share my friends' stories with more people.
People who are frustrated by the current mental health system, in which medicine often doesn't work and therapy is costly and time-consuming.
People who are open to new possibilities of envisioning a more joyful future. 
 
Your support will mean a lot to me, to people in the film, and the hundreds more students, researchers and activists of psychedelics.
 
 


~ SCHEDULE ~
 
In the last 4 months, I have:

submitted a 22-page application to the Sundance Documentary Fund, in which I outlined everything from story structure, artistic vision, to line budget and marketing strategy. While the chance of getting the funding is slim, spending dozens of hours strategizing everything about this documentary gave me a solid understanding of what I am doing with the whole project,
assembled a crew at the University College London, to film the London part of the documentary. The team directory is listed in the people section at psychedelicclubdoc.com 
interviewed, for 4 hours total, scholars in psychology, neuroscience, chemistry and philosophy. Among them are:

Robin Carhart-Harris, head of the world’s first psychedelic research center affiliated to a university, and

Karl Friston, one of the world’s most influential neuroscientists and whose papers have been cited for more than 230,000 times, 


collected 18 hours of footage with the UCL psychedelic society and its founder and president, including events and personal interviews 
pitched the documentary to everyone I could, including ~30 individuals working in psychedelics research/therapy at a meeting at Imperial College’s psychedelic research centre, 
consulted and received generous guidance from an Emmy-winning filmmaker, founder of Raindance Film Festival, and a former BBC interviewer. 

 
I’m currently at home organizing the footage, running this campaign, and doing more preparation work for future filming.
At the end of January, I will be heading to the Sundance Film Festival to volunteer for 9 days, and hopefully get to chat about this documentary with as many people as I can!
 
Here is the rest of the production schedule: 
 
GENERAL FILMING
March-April, 2020   San Francisco, Philadelphia, Princeton, New York City, Boston

interviews with students, researchers, professors & other relevant individuals
student club meetings (meditations, rituals, etc)
the 2nd Intercollegiate Psychedelic Summit at Harvard

June, 2020Amsterdam
a few subjects taking psychedelics (magic truffle) in Amsterdam, including the preparation, the trip, and the integration
POST-PRODUCTION
June-August, 2020
Finish the fine cut by the start of September
OUTREACH
from September, 2020, onwards

Submit the film to major film festivals like Sundance, Hot Docs, Sheffield Doc/Fest, and IDFA
Organize screenings on college campuses and organizations related to mental health, psychedelics, harm reduction, and consciousness studies

 
 
 
~ LAST WORDS ~
 
To be honest, I have no idea how much interest in this film there exists. I would imagine that many of you would be quite skeptical.  

Maybe we are being dumb.
And ignorant. And delusional. And overly idealistic. In which case, this documentary could still be quite entertaining. 
 
If you put aside the value judgment of how right these students are in their belief in and pursuit of using psychedelic drugs to eliminate mental sufferings, this documentary will still serve as an intimate archive of a few young individuals trying, not without doubt, to tackle some of the hardest problems in our society.
We may leave it to time and history to judge, perhaps through continuous reframing, what these students have been doing :)
 
If you have any questions, please let me know at: me@wendiyan.com

story:
Lavender Boy | Short Film

Mission Statement

As filmmakers, we try and make films that start a conversation and change the world. This film is no different. The goal of Lavender Boy is to entertain and educate because of the events of the lavender scare.

PERKS

We are super excited to have a wide variety of perks that will fit everyone's personality and needs. From the young creatives looking for an opportunity to the people that are contributing "just because"

Feel free to check out our perks and note that new perks will come out during the course of the campaign. And other cool things like:

  • Gift Card Giveaway
  • Free Premiere Tickets and more!

 

BUDGET BREAKDOWN

Below, we have our budget breakdown for how our $8,000 goal will be divided up. Lavender Boy is a 3-day shoot and these are approximate numbers.

  • Cast:                                         $1,000
  • Crew:                                        $3,325
  • Props & Art:                           $1,500
  • Gear Insurance:                    $750
  • Catering & Food:                  $700
  • Costume & Wardrobe:        $300
  • Location Fees:                     $200

                                 TOTAL  =  $7,775

 

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

         We understand that not everyone is able to contribute financially. And luckily, that doesn't mean you still can't contribute. Letting us use your 1950s style clothing or props, for example, will help us out tremendously. So if you have a location, props, a vehicle, etc that we can use for free email us at lavenderboyfilm@gmail.com

 

THE DIRECTOR

Donavan Edwards, Writer/Director

         Hello, for those of you who don't know me, my name is Donavan Edwards. I am a filmmaker based in Columbus, OH. I just want to say a quick thank you to all of you that have contributed so far it truly means a lot. As a filmmaker, I've dreamed of making a short film at this scale for a while and I feel like now is the right time. I originally started making videos when I was 14 yrs old, and throughout the years I've been able to watch myself grow as a man and as a filmmaker. These last couple of years have been a blast as I've been able to branch out and travel more as well as work with big companies and organizations such as; Microsoft. Muskingum University, MLG, CAAMP, Root Insurance and more! And it doesn't stop there as I've worked on a number of narrative and personal projects. I'm excited to work on this short film and bring my vision to life for everyone to see. Once again, thank you, everyone, for all the love and support and wish me luck!

MY SITE: https://www.donavanmyles.com 

 

THE TEAM

Brett Reiter, Producer

Greyson Mack, Cinematographer 

Juli Sasaki, Production Designer

Tisha Hanley, 1st AD

Aujolie Baker, Producer & 2nd AD

Angela Jernigan, Costume Designer

 

 

 

 

THANK YOU!

SINCERELY, 

Lavender Boy Film

story:
About the Team

Most of the crew has been congregated at MET Film School, in London, but they all come from different countries and backgrounds.

The director has studied art and film in Edinburgh, literature in Colombia and film, photography and acting in La Havana, Prague and New York.

This is an ambitious project, and we're bringing to it as much as we can to make it as great as it can possibly be. We have a team of passionate filmmakers and artists on their own craft (make up, music, sound, illustration) working very enthusiastically on the project. The only thing we're lacking is the financial support to bring it all to terms. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Most of the funds will be designated to make up and special effects, both in preproduction (make up) and post production (sound design). The rest will be for the film production basics (food, transport, location). And if we exceed our goal we'll be able to spend it on distribution, which means you'll have an even better chance to see the film at a proper screening in festivals!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can share our page so more people get to know about Ágata's story and the fantasy world she lives in. Follow #AGATASBUBBLES and see the process. You can ask questions and share the experience with us!

story:
WHO AM I ?

My name is Sophea Kim,

I am a Cambodian filmmaker, I was born here, I grew up, lived and worked in Cambodia. My 12 years working with foreign film productions has helped me to extend my experience, and allowed me to learn stories through many perspectives. Since 2007, I had the chance to work closely with Rithy Panh, Regis Wargnier, Chantal Akerman, Jeanne Labrune, Angelina Jolie,... and many more prestigious film directors from different parts of the world. Working with experienced filmmakers allowed me to open my mind and wander further into the world of cinema.

I decided to direct my own films because I think I am ready to tell the stories that I always wanted to tell. I am 35 now, and I have been through a lot in my life and this experience is my inspiration, and this is what I want to share in my films. I believe that films can connect and change people in some ways. As a new generation rising from a dark period, we have been passing by waves of changes and today our generation needs to find answers and to speak up! I want to find and tell my part and you can help me do that!

GREY FEATHER is my first film as a director

WHAT IS THE FILM ABOUT ?

The story talks about a Cambodian girl who confronts her own will, her own culture as she decides to free herself, to break the barriers she's been locked in for many years. Sarita RETH, our fabulous character challenges, not only women, but people in Cambodia, and the rest of the world to define the meaning of “Being Free”.

WHY I'M MAKING THIS FILM ?

The topic is very important, as I have been myself and other friends confronted with many questions about our culture. I see that most of us live in a locked world, where options are limited by society, or sometimes also by our own will. Only a few actually dare to bypass the rules they have been told; and when they dare to, fear and doubt are always around. This story is about CHOICES.

We live in a modern society now and people can more and more access and question everything, when thinking about our culture, I always wonder where it comes from and what value it has today, why it is so powerful?

How far we can go to against ourselves, our own roots, and a society where our culture has always been in our blood and build our own mindset. Education is very important, but I believe that our daily life has a huge power to inspires us the most. It is hard to leave those things behind. Some people might think to fight for their freedom, we only need strong commitment and strength to win it, but in the reality is not simple as that.

GREY FEATHER was produced with a very dedicated and professional crew. After some time in the editing studio, I know the production value of the film, and I believe that a proper post-production would be an amazing additional and essential gift to the film, and would allow that story to travel and captivate audience around the world. GREY FEATHER is my first film, and I already know that this is not my last one.

Any support from the team and from you, means so much to me, to my world and to my career. In Cambodia, it is very hard for filmmakers to get any support locally. You can also imagine what it takes as a female filmmaker to stand up and tell such a not-so-conventional story. But obstacles and strong winds won't discourage me from taking that road.

This film not only tells about Cambodian women and culture, but it is also a reflection for women all over the world, who face similar questions. Your contribution to THIS film will also help all the next films that I will do!!!

THE STORY SO FAR …

After 4 months working on the edit, the film is already here and it’s looking great. We are seeking for 5,000 USD to achieve the last step, a GOOD POST PRODUCTION: SOUND DESIGN + COLOUR GRADING + some VISUAL EFFECTS, before delivering “GREY FEATHER” out to world. These funds will be used to rent costly post-production facilities in Cambodia, Bangkok (and maybe France) - usually 500 to 1000 USD a day x 3 days -  and pay salaries to professional technicians who are working or will be soon working on finishing the film. That includes a travel fee for my team (Colorist, Sound Designer) and myself. Once post is done, we will also need a proper subtitling in French and Khmer language and to create Digital Cinema Package (DCP) that will require a few hard drives. The rest of the funds will be used as submission fees for film festivals that cost each time between 25USD to 75USD.

Aside your contribution makes you feel great by showing your support and trust to a debut Cambodian Female Filmmaker, you will get opportunities to be updated about our film selection, its premiers, its parties and production souvenirs.

And you will be part of creating something that will last longer than your own life!

In any case, the film will need to be done, in a proper way. Meeting the quality standard we are aiming at now depends on YOUR contributions. If at the end of the campaign, we could not reach our goal, we would finish the film with what we have. Please be sure that your contribution will be for the film and ONLY for the film.

CELEBRATE THE TEAM !

GREY FEATHER is made with love and it's a teamwork as is any film!!!

Without strong support from my friends and my wonderful crew, I wouldn’t be able to make this film. I want to express my gratitude for the support, inspiration and encouragements from Rithy Panh, Chantal Akerman, Sok Visal, Chandara So, Jean-Pierre Garcia, Cedric Eloy, Christine Chansou.

A BIG SHOUT OUT FOR A WONDERFUL FRIENDS, CAST & CREW !

  • JEREMIAH OVERMAN, my friend and talented DIRECTOR OF PHOTOGRAPHY:

We’ve met a bout a year and half ago while working on a feature film togther, since then we became friends and did together both fun and difficult projects.Jeremiah is a cinematographer, video editor and an all-around image wizzard. He started off ten years ago documenting the US skateboarding scene and making music videos - a passion he later continued developing at the Art Institute of Portland, while studying Digital Media Production. Today, he makes commercials, music videos and narrative films. Only in 2018, he shot three feature films, including “The Prey” by the acclaimed director Jimmy Henderson and “Young Love” by first time feature director Lomorpich Rithy. He has become very quickly recognised in the film industry and is very high demand.

  • MARTA KASZTELAN, PRODUCER and 1st AD

Marta is a human rights lawyer, freelance journalist and filmmaker. In all three capacities she works mainly on gender and for the advancement of women’s rights. It is that thematic that drew her to GREY FEATHER in the first place. Her most notable films, which she directed and produced, include “Pretty Radical” and “Real Autism”. These are short documentary films, which premiered online and both went viral. The first was commissioned by UK’s The Guardian and the second by Al Jazeera. Although originally from Poland, she has lived and worked in the UK, France, India and Cambodia.

  • SOPHEAKTRA PHONG: My best friend and the MOST RELIABLE PRODUCTION MANAGER in CAMBODIA

Sopheaktra, or just call her TRA, has begins her career in Film Production in late 2017 just right after she finished her university in Journalism. She works as Second AD with me in a local Feature films, “The Spell”, “Young Love” and a French Production’s Film “Onoda - 10000 Nights in the Jungle” lately.

Aside, she works on many International and local productions, included Features, TV series, shorts, documentaries, TVC and few campaigns related to environment, climate change programs.

  • SARITA RETH, LEAD ACTRESS

My favorite Actress of all times

Sarita’s passion for the film industry started at a young age after watching Hollywood actress Ange-lina Jolie star in the blockbuster film, Tomb Raider. The movie was popular among young Cambodians due to the film’s location shooting at the ancient temple ruins in Siem Reap, and Jolie’s advocacy for and close relationship to the Cambodian community. At the age of 17, Sarita started competing in beauty pageants and talent competitions, which eventually led her landing in full-time anchor for BBC Media Action’s TV series "Love9".

She starred in short films that include “Happiness” (2015), “The Dinner” (2016), “Kidnap” (2017), “The Interview” (2017), as well as several TV dramas. She has also appeared in several feature films including “Mind Cage” (2016), “Love To The Power of Four” (2016), and “HEX” (2017).

  • SAMUAL IZAC JAMES or SAM JAMES,

Fabulous male Actor

Sam and I met when working in Amit Dubey’s latest Feature film “The Spell”. From his background and skill, he is a great photographer and is better known for his creativity.  Moreover,I found something very special in him as an Actor, he’s got talent. when I talk about the concept of the film, he did say yes immediately. And I know I am so proud of my choice! Unfortunately, he had to leave Cambodia and settle down in Australia just few months after we finished the shooting of Grey Feather.

Today he keeps doing his amazing job in photography field.

  • Deeply thank you for the rest of crew that I cannot mention in here, otherwise the text will take 1km long ;-) But you're the best, and you know and I know! 

 

RISKS & CHALLENGES

There’s hardly any risk for you to take since the project is already far from its development state and even close to being finished! The footage are stored in multiple safe places, and the rough cut is already done. I put a lot of me in the this, and I will make the best of my best so that GREY FEATHER can be Premiered in the best possible Festival and also shown in many other events and places after that. Be sure that the film will not be ever abandoned, set aside or forgotten.

Only one challenge that we now face is to know which of the large festivals will take us first in the selection.

It has gone to some industry insiders and has had a great response in Cambodia and internationally.  Being described by Jean-Pierre Garcia (Film Festival Artistic Director and worldwide film consultant for over 40 years) , “A mise en scène that is sophisticated and a magnificent photography, almost too beautiful” and by a Variety Film critic “ It’s an engaging portrait of cross-cultural romance, self-determination and uncertainty about the future”. I do know that very few short films made in Cambodia have received this type of positive feedback, so I really believe it will find its audience here in Cambodia and somewhere in the world. 

But we have to keep in mind that film festival programmers are curating an event and not just looking at individual films.  The final film will be approximately 21 minutes and we will keep you posted in the blog about Festival selections.

THINGS YOU CAN DO TO SUPPORT THIS INDIE FILM :

There’s a lot of ways to help us to show your great supports to a Cambodian female filmmaker. Your voice is my voice. GREY FEATHER is a way to really kickstart my work as a director, and built my wings to fly and to make always better films.

Please help me to build them and I will open them and fly high with you!

SHARE, sharing is caring. You have just contributed to GREY FEATHER, and it would be very helpful if you could share this on social media and encourage people to get involved.  Use the Indiegogo share tools and voila. 

LOVE only, To really help social media algorithms then you need to love our posts not just like them.  Apparently, facebooks are a bit 'Meh' about likes. So reach for the heart.

Tweet the campaign and use the hashtags #GREYFEATHER #supportindiefilm #supportwomendirectors #supportcambodianfilms

This story is about CHOICES.We live in a modern society now and people can more and more access and question everything, when thinking about our culture, I always wonder where it comes from and what value it has today, why it is so powerful?How far we can go to against ourselves, our own roots, and a society where our culture has always been in our blood and build our own mindset. Education is very important, but I believe that our daily life has a huge power to inspires us the most. It is hard to leave those things behind. Some people might think to fight for their freedom, we only need strong commitment and strength to win it, but in the reality is not simple as that.GREY FEATHER was produced with a very dedicated and professional crew. After some time in the editing studio, I know the production value of the film, and I believe that a proper post-production would be an amazing additional and essential gift to the film, and would allow that story to travel and captivate audience around the world. GREY FEATHER is my first film, and I already know that this is not my last one.Any support from the team and from you, means so much to me, to my world and to my career. In Cambodia, it is very hard for filmmakers to get any support locally. You can also imagine what it takes as a female filmmaker to stand up and tell such a not-so-conventional story. But obstacles and strong winds won't discourage me from taking that road.This film not only tells about Cambodian women and culture, but it is also a reflection for women all over the world, who face similar questions. Your contribution to THIS film will also help all the next films that I will do!!!THE STORY SO FAR …After 4 months working on the edit, the film is already here and it’s looking great. We are seeking for 5,000 USD to achieve the last step, a GOOD POST PRODUCTION: SOUND DESIGN + COLOUR GRADING + some VISUAL EFFECTS, before delivering “GREY FEATHER” out to world. These funds will be used to rent costly post-production facilities in Cambodia, Bangkok (and maybe France) - usually 500 to 1000 USD a day x 3 days -  and pay salaries to professional technicians who are working or will be soon working on finishing the film. That includes a travel fee for my team (Colorist, Sound Designer) and myself. Once post is done, we will also need a proper subtitling in French and Khmer language and to create Digital Cinema Package (DCP) that will require a few hard drives. The rest of the funds will be used as submission fees for film festivals that cost each time between 25USD to 75USD.Aside your contribution makes you feel great by showing your support and trust to a debut Cambodian Female Filmmaker, you will get opportunities to be updated about our film selection, its premiers, its parties and production souvenirs.And you will be part of creating something that will last longer than your own life!In any case, the film will need to be done, in a proper way. Meeting the quality standard we are aiming at now depends on YOUR contributions. If at the end of the campaign, we could not reach our goal, we would finish the film with what we have. Please be sure that your contribution will be for the film and ONLY for the film.CELEBRATE THE TEAM !GREY FEATHER is made with love and it's a teamwork as is any film!!!Without strong support from my friends and my wonderful crew, I wouldn’t be able to make this film. I want to express my gratitude for the support, inspiration and encouragements from Rithy Panh, Chantal Akerman, Sok Visal, Chandara So, Jean-Pierre Garcia, Cedric Eloy, Christine Chansou.A BIG SHOUT OUT FOR A WONDERFUL FRIENDS, CAST & CREW !JEREMIAH OVERMAN, my friend and talented DIRECTOR OF PHOTOGRAPHY:We’ve met a bout a year and half ago while working on a feature film togther, since then we became friends and did together both fun and difficult projects.Jeremiah is a cinematographer, video editor and an all-around image wizzard. He started off ten years ago documenting the US skateboarding scene and making music videos - a passion he later continued developing at the Art Institute of Portland, while studying Digital Media Production. Today, he makes commercials, music videos and narrative films. Only in 2018, he shot three feature films, including “The Prey” by the acclaimed director Jimmy Henderson and “Young Love” by first time feature director Lomorpich Rithy. He has become very quickly recognised in the film industry and is very high demand.MARTA KASZTELAN, PRODUCER and 1st ADMarta is a human rights lawyer, freelance journalist and filmmaker. In all three capacities she works mainly on gender and for the advancement of women’s rights. It is that thematic that drew her to GREY FEATHER in the first place. Her most notable films, which she directed and produced, include “Pretty Radical” and “Real Autism”. These are short documentary films, which premiered online and both went viral. The first was commissioned by UK’s The Guardian and the second by Al Jazeera. Although originally from Poland, she has lived and worked in the UK, France, India and Cambodia.SOPHEAKTRA PHONG: My best friend and the MOST RELIABLE PRODUCTION MANAGER in CAMBODIASopheaktra, or just call her TRA, has begins her career in Film Production in late 2017 just right after she finished her university in Journalism. She works as Second AD with me in a local Feature films, “The Spell”, “Young Love” and a French Production’s Film “Onoda - 10000 Nights in the Jungle” lately.Aside, she works on many International and local productions, included Features, TV series, shorts, documentaries, TVC and few campaigns related to environment, climate change programs.SARITA RETH, LEAD ACTRESSMy favorite Actress of all timesSarita’s passion for the film industry started at a young age after watching Hollywood actress Ange-lina Jolie star in the blockbuster film, Tomb Raider. The movie was popular among young Cambodians due to the film’s location shooting at the ancient temple ruins in Siem Reap, and Jolie’s advocacy for and close relationship to the Cambodian community. At the age of 17, Sarita started competing in beauty pageants and talent competitions, which eventually led her landing in full-time anchor for BBC Media Action’s TV series "Love9".She starred in short films that include “Happiness” (2015), “The Dinner” (2016), “Kidnap” (2017), “The Interview” (2017), as well as several TV dramas. She has also appeared in several feature films including “Mind Cage” (2016), “Love To The Power of Four” (2016), and “HEX” (2017).SAMUAL IZAC JAMES or SAM JAMES,Fabulous male ActorSam and I met when working in Amit Dubey’s latest Feature film “The Spell”. From his background and skill, he is a great photographer and is better known for his creativity.  Moreover,I found something very special in him as an Actor, he’s got talent. when I talk about the concept of the film, he did say yes immediately. And I know I am so proud of my choice! Unfortunately, he had to leave Cambodia and settle down in Australia just few months after we finished the shooting of Grey Feather.Today he keeps doing his amazing job in photography field.Deeply thank you for the rest of crew that I cannot mention in here, otherwise the text will take 1km long ;-) But you're the best, and you know and I know!  RISKS & CHALLENGESThere’s hardly any risk for you to take since the project is already far from its development state and even close to being finished! The footage are stored in multiple safe places, and the rough cut is already done. I put a lot of me in the this, and I will make the best of my best so that GREY FEATHER can be Premiered in the best possible Festival and also shown in many other events and places after that. Be sure that the film will not be ever abandoned, set aside or forgotten.Only one challenge that we now face is to know which of the large festivals will take us first in the selection.It has gone to some industry insiders and has had a great response in Cambodia and internationally.  Being described by Jean-Pierre Garcia (Film Festival Artistic Director and worldwide film consultant for over 40 years) , “A mise en scène that is sophisticated and a magnificent photography, almost too beautiful” and by a Variety Film critic “ It’s an engaging portrait of cross-cultural romance, self-determination and uncertainty about the future”. I do know that very few short films made in Cambodia have received this type of positive feedback, so I really believe it will find its audience here in Cambodia and somewhere in the world. But we have to keep in mind that film festival programmers are curating an event and not just looking at individual films.  The final film will be approximately 21 minutes and we will keep you posted in the blog about Festival selections.THINGS YOU CAN DO TO SUPPORT THIS INDIE FILM :There’s a lot of ways to help us to show your great supports to a Cambodian female filmmaker. Your voice is my voice. GREY FEATHER is a way to really kickstart my work as a director, and built my wings to fly and to make always better films.Please help me to build them and I will open them and fly high with you!SHARE, sharing is caring. You have just contributed to GREY FEATHER, and it would be very helpful if you could share this on social media and encourage people to get involved.  Use the Indiegogo share tools and voila. LOVE only, To really help social media algorithms then you need to love our posts not just like them.  Apparently, facebooks are a bit 'Meh' about likes. So reach for the heart.Tweet the campaign and use the hashtags #GREYFEATHER #supportindiefilm #supportwomendirectors #supportcambodianfilms

story:
The Abraham Lincoln, Douglas Debates film tells the story of the lead up to the famous October 7, 1858 debate.  Lincoln and Douglas each have their supporters and are passionately preparing for this great political event. We touch on the Kansas/Nebraska Act, Popular Sovereignty, the Dred Scott case, Lecompton, Lincoln’s House Divide speech, La Compton and the Missouri Compromise.

The characters talk about the first four debates and mention the last two upcoming debates.  Even though there are so many intense and controversial topics to discuss, both Lincoln and Douglas focus their debate to the number one issue that is tearing the country apart, slavery. 

One of the reasons the Galesburg debate remains hugely significant is that at Knox College Abraham Lincoln for the first time talked at length about the immorality of slavery.  In today’s terms, the evils and immorality of slavery seem clear.  But, in 1858, tragically, people were living in a world where slavery was a reality and an issue that deeply divided people.  Even most people opposed to the evils of slavery did not talk in those terms.  People like that were thought to be radical extremists called Abolitionists.  Lincoln significantly changed the national debate and the hearts and minds when he laid out his case for why slavery was immoral and needed to end.

We have gone to great lengths to research the historical accuracy of this film.  We have many of the actual people, that was there at the debate represented, and have tried to incorporate their own words or actions in the dialog.  We have taken some liberty in adding a few people that were very important to the overall story.  Our hope is that people will want to learn their names, and the major issues leading up to this important debate.  

Short Summary

I am proud to be a storyteller.  I am an artist and a business person.  I have professionally worked in the entertainment business for a number of years.  I also have owned and operated several businesses and work in the corporate office as a manager for a fortune 10 company.  I am an artist; I love the craft of film making and I bring a strong business acumen.  

What We Need & What You Get

   Your name will be listed in the credits of our film. Sections are determined in the Perks description. We need to raise $15,000.  We have many amazing people that have been volunteering and interning on this project.  It has been a labor of love.  We are passionate about doing this project and telling this incredible story. 

    This is a period piece that will have great visuals and cinematic quality.  We would never be able to do a project of this scale without all of the incredibly hard-working volunteers and interns.

   In addition to all of our amazing volunteers, we will be hiring profession filmmakers.  This is where your contribution is desperately needed and where the funds will be allocated.  We need a professional team to capture and make this story come alive.  We will be hiring a line producer, cinematographer, 1st Assistant Director, 2nd Assistant Director, 2nd 2nd Assistant Director, Sound, Wardrobe, Hair and Makeup, Art Department.  We will be filming 6 days with one additional day on the front end for set up and one additional day on the back end for breakdown.   There will be 6-8 Production Assistants.   There are two large atmosphere days with over 75 background.  The other film days, we will have a 30+ background. 

   This is a very large and ambitious project.  Every penny will be used twice.  It is heavily volunteer based.  Your contribution is greatly appreciated!!!

The Impact

This is a very important story and we need your help to tell it to the world.  This is a great all-American story.  It is very patriot.  Lincoln is one of the most recognized individuals in modern human history.  He lived a difficult but extraordinary life.  He was a very unlikely candidate for the presidency of the United States.  Against overwhelming odds, he found a way, and he saved this country.  He rightfully has become a mythical figure.  Gaining a greater understanding of the man and the difficult choices he had to make and the painful journey he traveled, might give all of us a greater understanding of who we are as a people, a nation and a world. 

   I am wholly committed to this project and this story.  There are so many people that have contributed to this project.  There are exceptional individuals that have add so much to this project, because they too believe in this story and this project. 

Risks & Challenges

We have formed many contingency plans. Fortunately, we have a growing team to help us continue to anticipate and evaluate unexpected obstacles to help mitigate any challenges. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

This is a grassroots operation, and we would appreciate your help to get the word out and to make some noise about this great campaign!

One good way to get the word out is to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you so much again and we hope you will join us today!

story:
My name is Gemma Gallucci and I am a film student at Ithaca College. I am making Die Groteske in order to shed light on the lack of vulnerability that men feel they can share with their male peers and the negative effects that this has on one's emotional state.

So far our budget has reached around $1,000-1,100. With the price of possible re-shoots, scoring the film, and festival entry fees, this project could easily reach or surpass $1,500.

The budget up to this point consists of costuming and makeup, set design, 16mm Double X Film, transferring and developing, and craft services.

The Impact

By contributing to my film, you are directly impacting the future of my career. If I am able to fully fund Die Groteske, this means financial freedom to continue following my dream of being a filmmaker. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute money, other ways you could help are simply passing this campaign on, or sharing the film with friends and family once it is done.

story:
About Oinya's Prize

Mahir and Ahir, the parents of three children — Oinya, Iora, and Caroline — return home after an extended absence. Once settled at home, they attempt to return to their normal lives, but find they can’t, due to the lasting effects of trauma on the Ahir (the father) and, indirectly, on Mahir (the mother). A trophy won by the elder daughter Caroline, symbolizing the family unit, becomes the object of her younger sister Oinya's obsession.

The crisis of the short occurs when Oinya finally has the trophy in hand. As she triumphantly attempts to show her new prize to the family, she bumps into her mother Mahir, dropping the trophy and seeing it shatter. It appears the family may be close to their own breaking point as well. In a moment of clarity, Ahir’s discovery of his own inner strength rallies the family, and they pull together, reshaping the trophy into something new. As he begins to pick up the pieces, he realizes this is exactly what the family needs. 

One by one the family members join Ahir and they all begin to create something new. Inspired by a new sense of possibility, the family works together and end up creating a beautiful bowl in the shape of a heart. We see healing begin to take place and are left with the message that while some things cannot be put back the way they were before, they can be transformed into something new that has its own beauty.

So Who is Drawn from Valor? 

Drawn from Valor is a non-profit animation studio with a passion for helping children and families impacted by medical and mental health conditions. We partner with subject matter experts to create free resources that educate through engaging animated storytelling. We take viewers on empowering journeys to help them manage their conditions and live longer, healthier, happier lives.

Our creative team is made up of a core group of artists and writers with a long-standing passion for visual storytelling, while our administrative and social outreach teams are tireless in their pursuit of the means to connect people, not only to one another, but to the resources necessary to lead better lives.

Our first project, Kara & the (Not So) Dire Beastie, was completed in the summer of 2018 in partnership with Dr. Angelina Bernier, a pediatric endocrinologist from the University of Florida. This 8-episode series, available in both English and Spanish, was created to empower and educate children and their families in managing type 1 diabetes. The 28-minute project is part of Dr. Bernier's New Onset Diabetes Educator (NODE), an interactive website and eBook designed to help patients and their families understand type 1 diabetes, increase access to resources in remote locations, and help them retain important facts and recommended practices ultimately leading to improved health.

Why is Animation so Special? 

Younger kids often lack the tools or vocabulary to discuss and confront personal issues that are new to them. Animation is a safe, familiar way for them to explore similar problems and solutions. We know that with education, people are empowered to make healthier choices and children grow up to be stronger individuals. Studies have shown that children learn and understand material better — and faster — when it is presented in animated form. They say a picture is worth a thousand words; one second of animation can literally be up to 30 pictures or more.

    The Impact of PTSD / Trauma

    According to the National Center for PTSD, 60% of men and 50% of women will experience some form of trauma in their lives. Of those, varying percentages are at risk for developing PTSD based on the type of trauma they experienced (ranging from an estimated 3.8% impacted by natural disaster to 49% of rape survivors). Additionally anywhere from 14% to 43% of kids have or will encounter a traumatic event in their life. Of those children and teens who have experienced trauma, between 3% — 15% of girls and 1% — 6% of boys develop Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). 

    Because there is such a great need, we have now begun work on our long-term series, The Tales of the Golden Acorn, beginning with Oinya's Prize. This important series focuses on the impacts and effects of PTSD and trauma on families, shares the various paths to healing, and consistently returns to the core message there is always room for hope.

    Drawn from Valor wants people to know they and their loved ones are not alone. For this reason, we are kicking off this project on June 27, National PTSD Awareness Day to literally draw attention to PTSD while raising money to make Oinya's Prize. 

    Why is Oinya's Prize Important?

    Our goal is to give caregivers, children, friends, and their families the tools to learn important information whenever, wherever, and however they want. The animated worlds we create help make complex medical and mental health information accessible to children, and the fantastical stories we tell help them confront personal issues they may not normally feel comfortable addressing, or lack the tools to discuss on their own.

    The Risks & Challenges of Creating Oinya's Prize

    To make a ten minute short like this, our artists and team put in about 3.33 hours of time per second of finished animation. Additionally, each second of animation costs approximately $225. We've set an ambitious goal of $50,000 to begin to fund this 10-minute short film. We know that it will take a lot of work to get there, but we believe we can with your help. But even if we fall short, every dollar you donate to Oinya's Prize will go directly to the cost of animating the project. We are committed to helping kids and families learn about the many paths to healing when dealing with PTSD or trauma in a family setting. We hope you are too!

    Exciting Reward Levels

    Now that you've heard all about our exciting project, it's time to get to the fun stuff — the reward tiers! We have some fantastic rewards in store for you. Have you ever wondered what you would look like as a squirrel? You're in luck!! Ever wanted to be the voice in a cartoon? We have that for you, too! There's hopefully a bit of everything for everyone, and we'll be offering a couple of special, limited-time-only rewards along the way. There are levels priced for everyone, and all contributions will get a downloadable coloring book page, so you can draw along with us.

    Join in the Fun!

    We want you to get involved and draw along with us as we raise funds to bring the short from pre-production to the big screen. Between now and August 10, you can upload your hope-themed art or coloring book pages to social media using the hashtags #drawnfromvalor and #Draw4Hope. We will be hosting weekly online live art events called “Draw-Alongs” focused on different hope-themed hashtags on Drawn from Valor’s Facebook and Instagram feeds. We hope you'll share your own art with us and help us draw awareness to PTSD and the message that, no matter how dire a situation may seem, there is always a reason to hope!

    We deeply believe in the importance of producing this work, but we can’t do it alone. Making our work freely available means that we rely on the generosity of people like you to help us make this happen. Whether you can offer skills and time as a volunteer, or financial support, any contribution large or small helps us provide those in need with the information to lead longer, healthier, happier lives.
