Now that you've heard all about our exciting project, it's time to get to the fun stuff — the reward tiers! We have some fantastic rewards in store for you. Have you ever wondered what you would look like as a squirrel? You're in luck!! Ever wanted to be the voice in a cartoon? We have that for you, too! There's hopefully a bit of everything for everyone, and we'll be offering a couple of special, limited-time-only rewards along the way. There are levels priced for everyone, and all contributions will get a downloadable coloring book page, so you can draw along with us.
Join in the Fun!
We want you to get involved and draw along with us as we raise funds to bring the short from pre-production to the big screen. Between now and August 10, you can upload your hope-themed art or coloring book pages to social media using the hashtags #drawnfromvalor and #Draw4Hope. We will be hosting weekly online live art events called “Draw-Alongs” focused on different hope-themed hashtags on Drawn from Valor’s Facebook and Instagram feeds. We hope you'll share your own art with us and help us draw awareness to PTSD and the message that, no matter how dire a situation may seem, there is always a reason to hope!
We deeply believe in the importance of producing this work, but we can’t do it alone. Making our work freely available means that we rely on the generosity of people like you to help us make this happen. Whether you can offer skills and time as a volunteer, or financial support, any contribution large or small helps us provide those in need with the information to lead longer, healthier, happier lives.

story:
STORY

My name is Mark Green I'm from the Bronx, NY and I'm an actor, Writer and Director. Growing up in the Bronx I always had the dream of becoming an actor and performer but as a kid I was a bit afraid to go after that dream. In the environment where I was you were looked at as weird If you followed big dreams like being an actor or artist and I didn't want to stand out like that so I didn't really pursue the dream until my senior year in Highschool when I did the musical "Smokey Joe's cafe" and that's when my love for musicals was born. I fell in love with other musicals like "Hairspray", "Once on This Island", and even the oldies like "Singing in the Rain". There was one movie called "Highschool Musical" that had everything I loved in it (Acting, Singing, Dancing, and Basketball). I watched that movie many times in hopes that one day I could be in a film like that.     "I Believe" will be that movie and with your help that dream can be a reality.  This film will not only help me realize my dream but also the dream of my friends. I know a lot of talented people  who don't get many opportunities because in this industry there's not enough to go around. It is very much about who you know or who knows you and If your talent isn't seen by the right people then it's hard for you to move forward in the business. I believe my mission on this earth is to help people, so with this campaign I intend on accomplishing that mission.

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We will need $50,000 to film this movie, movies like this usually cost in the millions but we are thinking realistically. We believe that with the team we have and with God's help we will be able to film something amazing. Here is a breakdown of where the money will go:-
  • $20,000: The actors (20) & extras (50)
  • $10,000: Production team (Director of Photography, AD, Sound designer, Grip, PA's)/10 days
  • $10,000: Locations ( the school for 7 days), ( 2 restaurants), (2 houses), (Lounge), (Theater)
  • $2,500: Wardrobe
  • $2,500: Permits/fees
  • The perks that you can get for donating are:- T-Shirts, soundtrack from the film, a copy of the film, tickets to the premier, Invite to the wrap party/live concert, Your own song, invitation to the set, an opportunity to be a part of the cast, a chance for your idea to be in the film
  • If we do not reach our goal most of the funds we have will go into paying the actors and the production team, we will however still be giving half of our profits to disease relief funds

The Impact

This is not just a happy go lucky Musical, it also deals with real issues of life such as poverty, not fitting in, and health issues like Alzheimer's, Cancer, and PTSD. I wanted to shed awareness on these issues because I have come across these issues in my family and some of the actors involved in this project have dealt with these issues in their families, that's why half the profit that we get from this film will go towards disease relief funds.   

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you in advance for your help, remember every little bit counts. Please also help us get the word out to your friends and family, use the indiegogo share tools and let's make this happen.

I BELIEVE!

story:
Hey there! Our names are Chris Ferguson & Kyla McIlwee and we are so thrilled to be sharing our current project: a 3-5 documentary film series under our new organization, Resilience is.

Our Mission: To explore and promote the solutions humans are currently designing to effectively adapt to the changes of our environment and the desires of our culture. This summer we will be filming our documentary series along the remote south coast of Newfoundland while sailing & living aboard a 30 ft C&C (1976) for 3 months.

As mixology would have it,

Chris is an iced afternoon libation, containing one third salty sailor, equal parts storyteller of documentary film & the written word, with a zesty garnish of adventure.

Kyla is your coziest community organizing beverage, with a rich splash of one of the creamiest off-menu milks with her recently completed Master’s in Public Health, and topped with an exotic spice mix of interviewing experience.

Since the early part of the year, Kyla & Chris have been working hard researching the resilient culture of Newfoundland, collaborating with a list of special people on the island in developing the concept for the film, as well as having fun creating this campaign!

We can’t thank you enough for supporting our documentary film series and we had such a good time creating these perks for everyone! Even if you are here simply perusing our page or don’t have the extra beer money to donate, there’s still many ways you can help!

Share this campaign via email, Facebook & Instagram with these hashtags:

#resilienceis  &  #resilienceisNewfoundland

Check us out! www.resilienceis.org & follow us on Instagram @ouresilienceis

ps. This Resilience is crowdfund video was edited by the one and only:

Michael Weybret II www.michaelweybret.com II @dosomethingcool

 

Where is Newfoundland?

It wasn’t too long ago when we were asking the same question. Below is a summary about this North Atlantic island’s history and why the Newfoundland outport towns are some of the first communities to experience the modern day whiplash of resource mismanagement & are now showing the world what it takes to properly adapt and recover from such challenges.

 

 

“In 1968 the cod catch (off the coast of Newfoundland) peaked at 810,000 tons, approximately three times more than the maximum yearly catch achieved before the super-trawlers. Approximately 8 million tons of cod were caught between 1647 and 1750 (103 years), a period encompassing 25 to 40 cod generations. The factory trawlers took the same amount in 5 years.”(1)

The Future.

These short films will be submitted for the North American festival circuit in the upcoming year, 2020. After the circuit, the series has a great potential to be utilized by institutions in Newfoundland and programs world-wide with a focus on resilience, with the final goal of making the films available to the public.

 

  1. Ransom A. Myers; Jeffrey A. Hutchings; Nicholas J. Barrowman (1997). "Why do fish stocks collapse? The example of cod in Atlantic Canada" (PDF). Ecological Applications.

 

Bout time we talk about money

We want to be completely transparent with our loyal donors, so here is a breakdown of our major production costs:

 

As you can see, our greatest investment will allow us to live in our new floating home for the next 3.5 months. We are getting a killer deal from our friend and boat owner, Miguel, who is also one of our collaborators at Memorial University in St. John's, Newfoundland. 

 

Thank you so much for your contribution!

 

Warmly, 

Chris & Kyla

story:
Short Summary

"Christopher Kahler exited the womb with a video camera in hand and knew at an early age that filmmaking would be his passion" is what I should say at this junction, but I won't. I did some stop motion animation and some weirdo ninja movies with my friends when we were kids just for laughs. I was into music by high school because being a rock star was an appealing choice not listed as a career on aptitude testing, but was still a great way to meet girls. I ended up in the orchestra since my grandmother had taught me how to read music which is about as unexciting to high school girls as it sounds.

Fast forward a few years and I've scribbled out and recorded my first horror themed score to play at my buddy's annual Halloween party. People asked "What movie is this from ?". It's not. I wrote it. "Well it should be in a movie." After a few beers, I agree and start looking online to make that happen. It does. I get a VHS movie of my music in a horror movie. It plays over the opening credits of a local stripper in the shower getting fake blood splashed on her fake boobs. It's not scary. I move into the production aspect of filmmaking.

Recently, I was stuck in traffic and mindlessly singing along to Motorhead when the lyrics really hit me:

'He moves so slowly, but he's coming after you

Nowhere to run or hide, not a thing that you can do

You're on his mind, you're on his mind....'

Damn ! I need to do my own slasher movie with catchy music and fully utilize the multiple suspect storyline. Everybody is doing 80s style so what if I took it back a bit to where it all started ? A GIALLO !

I've worked with dozens of talented people over the years, but would they be down for it ? YES ! I might speed babble when I talk on set because I get excited over details, but the edits tend to prove I'm pretty good at what I do (even won a few awards along the way). Also, I can usually do it on a limited budget since I can work around the locations I'm given. Unfortunately, I need to pay for a few more locations and props this time around which is why I'm not so excited to be asking for your help...

What We Need & What You Get

I've been lucky enough (and basically guerrilla enough) to get a lot of my locations for free so far which I wear as a badge of thriftiness to making this movie. That's not to say the production itself has costed nothing. I've dumped my savings into it between flights, food, gas money, etc. because I think it's a cool movie. No matter how cool it might be, my free location scenes are running out quickly and the places, wardrobes, and props for certain scenes coming up are adding up quickly.

I'm not asking for tens of thousands of dollars. Far from it actually. I just need enough to finish this movie I've already started. Every dollar literally gets you involved with an IMDb and movie credit because I don't believe that a social media shout-out properly acknowledges your contribution. Posters and DVDs are an affordable perk, t-shirts are available, and if you wanna go there, the limited edition vinyl LPs of the soundtrack are well within reach. You're doing me a favor and not the other way around. I appreciate it and want to reciprocate appropriately because I literally could not finish this movie within the next few months without you.

The Impact

 I love the rich lighting, lush music, beautiful people, brutal killings, and twist ending as much as every other giallo fan so I decided to make one myself for selfish reasons. More importantly, I've made a concerted effort to keep the plot focused on the story. This won't replace 'Deep Red' as your favorite, but hopefully a 'Steal Your Face' DVD can share the same shelf in everyone's collection.

Risks & Challenges

I suck at asking for help which is why most of this movie is or has been shot on exterior Chicago locations. The few extraordinary interiors fell into my lap by chance and as far as gialli go, these are a must. I can't rewrite other interior scenes to "just make them happen" without them looking like they were shot to "just make them happen" since they are integral to the overall story. I try to make every shot look like a painting whether it's just an establishing shot or a closeup of someone getting stabbed (and there are a lot of people getting stabbed in this movie).

If I absolutely didn't need help to secure these locations, I wouldn't be on IndiGoGo, but S&M bondage chambers and accompanying wardrobe won't come cheap so here I am !

Other Ways You Can Help

You can share this (which you won't) to your friends to share this (which they won't).

It is what it is LOL

You can share this (which you won't) to your friends to share this (which they won't).
It is what it is LOL

story:
Summary:

I know what you're asking. Why is the raise goal so high? Well, it's that way for a reason. The film itself has been funded to completion. However, additional funds are needed for marketing and outreach. The funding structure is not fixed, but rather provides room for marketing costs. Without successful marketing, the goal of health care reform will not be achieved. Please consider contributing just $10.  Thank you for your support!

 

About The Film:

Useful Links:

-Linkedin for Paul Roberts (Executive Producer and Writer of the film)

-Diamond View Studios (production studio for the film)

 

My name is Paul Roberts, and I am the executive producer and writer of the healthcare reform documentary, Diagnosing Healthcare. By trade, I am a veteran RN case manager and the owner of Roberts Consulting, a medical case management firm. Currently, medical case management is only utilized in about 10% of the larger health care market. My vision is to expand these services to the wider market, thereby reducing the burden of cost on the system, while at the same time improving the quality of care delivered. In this endeavor, I developed an alternative health care plan, which I dubbed, "Coordinated Care for All”. This plan offers a 40% cost savings over "Medicare for All", a savings of $1.4 Trillion annually, while improving quality. The plan was endorsed by the Case Management Society of America, as featured in their Nov 2019 edition of CMSA Today. While all of this can be applied to a model for a single-payer source (Universal Healthcare), the same ideas can be applied to the private sector as well. The allowance of pre-existing conditions and competition within the private health care sector are also inclusive in the plan. To learn more about the plan, please visit my blog.

Lawmakers have expressed enthusiasm. However, attempts to introduce the plan through a Bill in congress have so far been ineffective. For that reason, I had the idea of creating a documentary to introduce the plan to the general public, in hopes of inspiring a grassroots uprising that will places pressure on congress to enact change for the better.

Through dynamic and engaging footage, the film identifies the most problematic areas of the current mainstream health care system. In particular, these problems include: the rising cost of healthcare; lack of insurance coverage; treatment of symptoms instead of prevention (root source); inefficiency in healthcare delivery; lack of access to care; debate regarding privacy vs coordination of care; barriers to legislative progress (special interests); pharmaceutical deregulation; differential billing practices by hospital/surgical centers; unconsolidated medical records; patient/provider empowerment vs corporate interest. In addition to my plan, the film features an exploration of the free-market health care system, an affordable alternative to traditional health insurance.

What We Need & What You Get

While filming of the movie has completed, your support is needed to finish the project. An additional funds are needed for marketing and distribution of the film.

Rewards:

A: $15 - Refrigerator Magnet
B: $30 - Signed Movie Poster
C: $50 - B + Private Movie Download + Associate Producer Credit
D: $100 - B + C + Producer Credit
E: $500 - B + C + Authentic Movie Clapper and Executive Producer Credit
F: $1000 - B + C + D + Invitation for two at a reception dinner with members of the cast/crew in Tampa, FL (travel not included)

 

The Impact

With your support, we can achieve the goals of inspiring a grassroots movement in order to change health care for the better and to improve the lives of all Americans, if not those of other countries as well.

Risks & Challenges

Although I am a first time filmmaker, I am collaborating with a 5-time Emmy Award winning studio, Diamond View Studios. I am also consulting with leaders of the independent film making industry, such as John Reiss. The film will still be completed. However, the more funds we raise, the better our position will be for outreach and marketing, which is why the high raise goal.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people can't contribute, which I understand. However, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please get the word out on social media and make noise about the campaign.

Some people can't contribute, which I understand. However, that doesn't mean you can't help:
Please get the word out on social media and make noise about the campaign.

story:
Inspired by a true story, Off Beat is a light-hearted drama about an overweight pizza delivery guy, who stumbles upon the world of ballroom dancing and meets Wendy, an unassuming receptionist at a dance studio. Through their connection and chemistry the two find together, they will both have to overcome their insecurities to compete at a ballroom dance competition. Here are some scenes from the storyboards for the film:

 

This 15-minute short film is the Boston University Master’s thesis project for Derin Kiyak, Saad Yousuf, Eric Moots, and Songxin Xie. The team met through the Cinema and Media Production MFA program at Boston University, and quickly began work on the project together.

The end goal for this film is to be shown at film festivals across the world and showcase all of the talent that the crew has, but we can’t make this film without you!

Derin Kiyak, Writer and Director: Derin is a writer/director with a passion to create engaging visual stories. He has created many short films, several of which have won awards in film festivals all over the country. He's currently in Boston University's Graduate Film program pursuing his MFA and working as a Teaching Assistant. Some of his hobbies include video games, movies and ballroom dancing. He's looking forward to making this film a fun and emotional ride for the audience. 

Saad Yousuf, Cinematographer: Saad, originally from Pakistan, came to Boston to fulfill his dream as  a cinematographer. Prior to his Masters, Saad has done his Bachelors in  Film and Television production where soon after he gained incredible  experience working with various production and advertising companies in Pakistan.

Eric Moots, Producer: After growing up in Central Florida, Eric moved up to warm, sunny Boston for college. During his time at Boston University, he has received his Bachelor’s degree and is six months away from his Master’s degree in Television Producing and Management. He has produced several films that have received acclaim and acceptance to a number of film festivals including IFFB and the Redstones.

Songxin Xie, Producer and Co-Editor: Coming from a journalism background, Songxin fell in love with production when creating video contents for a magazine in Columbia, Missouri where she went to school. She then came to the BU film program learn and work with filmmaking enthusiasts like her. She producing and editing. She says everything she edits or produces to be perfect.

James Repetti: James began dancing as a child and has competed in and teaches Latin, Rhythm, Standard, and Smooth. James is a registered professional through the NDCA and a certified teacher through the USISTD. In 2015 he became the United States National Vice Champion in American Rhythm and has since focused primarily on his teaching. With over a decade of teaching experience and involvement in the collegiate circuit, James serves as the coach of all four styles for both Stony Brook and Hofstra University’s Ballroom Dance Teams and also privately coaches individual couples from across the country. His students have gone on to compete professionally, as well as to become national champions in their respective styles and levels.

Ava Morrison, Production Designer: Ava is a junior studying at Boston University. She is excited to have the opportunity to help bring this world to life through the production design. She's ready to take the dive into the world of Ballroom dance, which she was unfamiliar with before this experience. Previously, she has worked in the Scenic Art Department

As a student film, we don’t have the budget of a major motion picture. Despite this, we do have costs that are going to add up quickly. We need the support of backers, such as yourself, to make this story a reality.

In addition to the costs that come with making a short film, we have several costs that are unique to Off-Beat that we will need to be able to pay.

Here’s where your money will be going:

Locations: To rent a ballroom and dance studio, it’s going to cost us. While there are options for these locations on campus, the discounted rate will still take up a good portion of the budget.

Production Design: Even with the perfect ballroom and dance studio, a lot of work will need to be done to make them look perfect for the film. Dressing up the sets with decorations to match our vision will take time and money.

Food: Anyone who has ever been on a set will tell you that without proper craft services, the film will suffer. Our crew is being generous volunteering their time to help us create this project, the least we could do is provide a good meal every single day they’re on set.

Special Equipment: While Boston University is providing most of the equipment we will be using, there is some specific equipment that we will need to go outside of the school to get. To create the film the way that we have always imagined it, this equipment is necessary.

This is the minimum amount of money we need to make this film. Any additional funds we receive will help us take this film to the next level and add a layer of polish on top.

Risks and challenges:

With every film ever made, there are potential risks that put the film in danger of being disrupted or derailed. Our team has taken a careful look at these risks and identified ways to mitigate or entirely avoid all of them.

Weather is an ever-present issue for filmmaking. From halting production to wait on the rain to being rained out entirely, film crews always need to be cognisant of the weather. We have looked into this and identified a number of cover sets that we can use in the case of bad weather during the time of filming.

Thirty years ago, filmmakers needed to be worried about the damage of their film while they were shooting. We no longer have to as we are shooting entirely digital, but that does not completely prevent the danger of losing everything filmed. Our crew is planning on using RAID systems to make sure that we will never be completely without what we film during production.

We believe our crew is talented enough to overcome any of the obstacles we face during the course of pre-production, production, and post-production.
story_txt: Inspired by a true story, Off Beat is a light-hearted drama about an overweight pizza delivery guy, who stumbles upon the world of ballroom dancing and meets Wendy, an unassuming receptionist at a dance studio. Through their connection and chemistry the two find together, they will both have to overcome their insecurities to compete at a ballroom dance competition. story:
Message from Director Ray Santisteban


As we envision and work for a future absent of hate, division and inequity, we can learn from the legacy of the first Rainbow Coalition, a groundbreaking alliance that rocked Chicago in the 1960s and spread.

This year is the 50th Anniversary of the formation of this movement, which united members of Chicago's Black, Latinx and Southern White communities. It also marks 50 years since Fred Hampton was murdered.

Help tell the story! Donate now to the indiegogo campaign to cover the cost of licensing rare archival footage needed to prepare this feature length film for its festival premiere and anticipated national PBS broadcast.

**Thanks to Working Films for their assistance in shaping our films message.


What We Need and What You Get

We need to raise $20,000 to cover the cost of licensing footage from network television collections and special archives and preparation for festival exhibition and broadcast.

We will reward you with tons of gratitude, and regular updates on the project and the film’s release, and a lot of other cool things the higher your contribution. The poster design is underway by award-winning artist Yen Tan, a preview of which we will have shortly. Ray is offering 60-minute (phone or zoom) film consultations for contributors at the $500 level. (Besides making this film, he’s an expert producer/director of historical documentaries, a cinematographer, a writer, and a ton of fun to talk to.)

Other rewards include complimentary seating and perks for festival and special screenings, autographed posters, and digital postcards.

The Impact

Bridging past and present, The First Rainbow Coalition examines the legacy of an unlikely coalition that defied racial divisions.

Eloquent and seamless, the film brings to life a history resonant today, and will promote dialogue not just about the 1960s, but about urgent contemporary discussions on race and class in the United States.

story:
Sophie Parens and Taylor Washington are filmmakers based in Brooklyn, New York. They are passionate about telling stories that celebrate survival, resilience, and inspire positive change. This campaign is especially important to them to tell now, as they see how disconnected their peers have already become from this part of history. Taylor and Sophie believe that in a political climate that encourages xenophobia, we all have a responsibility to raise our voice and fight history from repeating itself.

All of the money raised in this campaign will go to funding the post-production needs essential to finish this film. This includes color correction, sound mix, score, stock footage, final editing, and film festival submission fees. Every single dollar is appreciated!

story:
Consider This Your Cordial Invitation

Board Games is a feature length film currently in pre-production with a scheduled shoot of January 10th - February 2nd 2020.

The film is a whodunnit for the modern era.

 

Six college students find themselves in the middle of a grisly mystery after a house party gets out of hand.

Elijah, Jeffrey, Scarlet, Emily, Gavin, and Liz were not planning for things to get this screwed up.  Some were escaping something, some were embracing something new. It was just supposed to be another house party, not unlike the hundreds that take place on every college campus. But this one was different.

Elijah's apartment is destroyed, and the group has no memory of the night before. The only thing that's certain is they just found a dead body, and the group has a creeping suspicion that someone who spent the night might be responsible.

A contemporary twist on a classic genre, Board Games is an intense, mysterious thriller about today's generation.

 

Making a feature length film isn't cheap, and making one for $20,000 isn't easy.

The primary expense we've dedicated the budget to is the purchasing, processing, and transferring costs of the 16mm film stock we will be shooting the film on. The entirety of our camera crew has experience shooting on film. 

The process of working with celluloid film is laborious, and much more costly than shooting on traditional digital cameras. However, we at Board Games adore the color profile and visual texture that shooting on film gives us, for which the images below can attest.

"16mm" Dir: Tyler McClellan (2019)

"Deal" Dir: Timothy Kandra (Creative Producer) (2019)

"Into the Night" Dir: Dakota Cerro (Gaffer) (2019)

 

The other large expense for a film like Board Games is the production design. The set, costumes, and art direction all go hand in hand in crafting a tense, nail-biting mystery. Add on top of that an original score recorded with a live orchestra, special FX, extra equipment costs, and food for the cast and crew, it does start to add up.

See below for a more detailed breakdown of our budget!

 

 

Want to meet more of the crew? Check out our instagram at @boardgamesfilm for regular Meet the Crew updates!

 

We understand that there are a large majority of risks that going into making a feature film. 

Everything that can go wrong on a film set, likely will go wrong. We have no intentions of being anything but open and honest with our backers when problems eventually arise. Filmmaking is all about problem solving, be them small discrepancies on the day, or finding long term solutions to any issues on set or in post-production.

 

From the satisfaction of making a great film at the end of the day, to the excitement of joining along in the filmmaking process, to our wide selection of perks, we want Board Games to be a worthwhile investment for you.

Show off your support with our Headwear tier or our Signed Poster, or for a little extra you can become an Associate or even an Executive Producer on the film! Join the filmmakers for a Video Chat or just accept a humble, digital thank you card from the cast and crew. The choice is yours!

 

Of course, not everyone interested in helping with Board Games will be able to donate. We understand that and thank you for your time and consideration so far.

If you are still interested in helping out but aren't in the position to make a donation right now, we ask that you please spread the word and share this project as much as you possibly can. Our best chance at funding this project is by getting as many eyes on it as we can.

 

From the bottom of the hearts of every cast and crew member, we want to say thank you. Thank you for reading this much about our passion project. We would love for you to come along for the ride with us.

Consider this your cordial invitation.

story:
Our team is comprised of young, diverse creatives who care about putting out quality content.

While there are many people offering their talents to our film, allow us to introduce you to a couple of our key roles: 

Madelyn Rideout (Writer/Director)

Madelyn Rideout is a recent Concordia graduate with several short films under her belt. Her screenplay for The Sex Act gained her a place as a finalist in the Screencraft 2017 short screenplay competition. She cares deeply about creating female-driven content and cannot wait to begin directing The Sex Act!

Gerardo Alcaine

Originally from El Salvador, Gerardo Alcaine recently graduated from Concordia University and has since been working as the creative director for a local Montreal magazine (fm2) and as a videographer for Productions L'Eloi. He is constantly seeking out projects in which he can work alongside diverse creatives, and continues to push himself to create quality images and video content.

*our cast and crew will be paid out of pocket 

Unfortunately there are things that we simply cannot avoid spending money on. Here is a breakdown of what we need and why: 

Lighting Rental while we only need several lights and stands for our shoot, lights are darn expensive! Renting lights in order to make our film look its best is the biggest chunk of our budget.

Grip Rental the most boring rental, but the foundation of any film set. Our grip rental includes stands for lighting and sandbags to safely hold those heavy stands in place.

Craft food, glorious food. We need to keep our team fed throughout our shoot! 

Wardrobe/Props our film is set in the 1970s, and we need it to look that way. Our art team has been collecting donated vintage items from friends and family, but we are going to need more in order to dress our sizeable cast and set.

Set Rental film sets can be fun and exciting, but also extremely chaotic. Most people do not want them inside their own homes. We have decided to rent a large house to shoot in, a la Airbnb. 

Truck Rental we need to get those stands and sandbags around somehow, and Madelyn's dad won't let us use his Honda civic! 

In Ontario, Canada, there has been a heated debate on the topic of sex ed amongst educators, parents, and religious leaders. In 2015 a curriculum that hadn't been changed since the 1990s finally got a much needed update. This change to the curriculum was met with backlash and protest, mostly over the introduction of progressive topics, such as the LGBT+ community, gender identity and sexual orientation, and the importance of consent. However, our Ontario government has recently changed, and steps have been taken to roll back the curriculum to its outdated version. Our protagonist, Ellen, dealt with what she believed to be an outdated curriculum in the 1970s. While our short film is funny, timely, and refreshing, the risk of losing an updated sex ed curriculum is not funny. It's easy to leave school and never take a math class again (thank goodness), but regardless of our education, we will continue to live with our sexuality, gender, and evolving bodies and identities for the rest of our lives. Comprehensive sex education allows us to lead healthier lives, both mentally and physically. 

We think we have a powerful short film on our hands, and we desperately want to share it with the world. What if we could change the way one person thinks about sex ed? That would be awesome!

Some More Reasons for You to Donate: 

  • You have a family member or friend working on our film!
  • You love to support diverse and independent film projects!
  • You love our amazing perks!

Thank you SO MUCH for visiting our page. Any support means the world to us! If you are unable to donate, please share our campaign with your friends and family! There are buttons on this page that allow you to easily share this Indiegogo Campaign on your social media.

story:
Why Are You Raising Money?

As an actor my future has more often than not been in the hands of other people. Let me give you my "favorite" example: Back in 2014 I booked a role opposite Amy Poehler in a film called The Nest (later retitled Sisters). Not only was this my first Hollywood studio film booking- I was going to get to act with one of my comedy idols. A day before the shoot date I was picked up and driven to Long Island for my fitting. There I saw the Executive Producer and we laughed together, I was fitted by the lovely costume department, took a few over enthusatic selfies in the trailer, and went back to NYC with a stupid grin of ecstasy plastered on my face. The next day I woke up extra early, worked out, drank a bunch of water, meditated, stretched, and imagined how great the day was going to be. Around 3PM, I gathered my things and headed out the door to meet the van going to set. As I turned the corner out of my building, my phone rang. It was a 212 number (which is ALWAYS exciting when you're an actor in NYC). I answered: "Hello?". A man's voice answered back "Hi Julia. This is Mike I'm calling from The Nest." "Hi Mike. I'm on the way to the van right now!" Mike paused and then he said "So, I know that this was on your list of fun things to do today...but unfortunately we had to cut your scene. I'm sorry". I acted like it wasn't a big deal, thanked Mike, and hung up. And just like that...everything sucked. 

This wouldn't be the first time I would be cut out of something. Or a huge National Network commercial I shot wouldn't air. Or I would be heart broken because I didn't book a life changing role. In fact, since then I've barely booked anything at all. As an actor- I don't fit into a box. So I decided enough was enough and I got back to my roots as a creator and wrote my television pilot Top Dog.  

What is Top Dog about?

Katie McKenna, a struggling plus-sized actress is smack in the middle of a spiritual crisis about pursuing a career in show business. When a series of kismet events propel her toward the chance at a more meaningful life working with dogs, she follows the scent to Los Angeles where she soon discovers she can’t shake the spotlight just yet because fate has led her into the lap of the largest & most successful talent agency...for dogs. 

The series follows Katie McKenna’s surprising rise in the company of Top Dog and the beginning of her journey in self discovery. It’s a story about enlightenment, about letting go and giving in, about self acceptance, about fighting ego, about what happens when you get to the TOP. It’s a story that asks “can you ever really get to the top?” and “what IS the top anyway?” 

So...What Do You Need From My Life?

Support (in the form of money). Have you ever had a friend email you a link to their independent film or video they put their heart & soul into but when you click on the link your heart sinks because it sounds and looks like it was shot on a first generation iPhone inside a garbage compactor? I REALLY care about the quality of my pilot Top Dog and I want to be taken seriously as an independent content creator. 

I shot 90% of the pilot using my own money I made bartending in a job I despise. But alas, I am now broke and am putting my pride aside to ask for help. In order to finish my pilot I need to shoot an elaborate opening scene which will require a budget for the following things. 

CREW (a professional Cinematographer, A professional Sound Operator, Camera Assistants, Productions Assistants, Etc.)

Locations, Lenses, Actors

Post Production

WHO the heck are you?

ulia Tokarz is a New York based actress, writer, director, & dog lover who has a BFA in Acting from LIU CW Post. Julia can be seen opposite comedian Chris D’Elia as his quirky assistant, Patty, in Heather Graham’s comedy Half Magic. Some of her other acting credits include The Last OG (TBS), Inside Amy Schumer (Comedy Central), Blue Bloods (CBS), & The Following (FOX). You may also have seen her with Amy Poehler in the feature film Sisters ....oh wait, no, her scene was cut out of that movie. 

Julia got her start in comedy training at UCB-NY from 2008-2012. The award winning comedy webseries she wrote & starred in, It's Not Okay, Cupid! has screened at festivals across the country and was featured in Backstage Magazine. She also created a series of YouTube sketches about millennials which won no awards. 

Why Does This Project Matter?

This story was born out of my own frustrations and blocks with being a plus sized actress who has a desire to change the world. I often find myself struggling with the questions “what is my purpose in this life?” and “what am I doing that matters?” I believe everyone has asked themselves these questions at some point in their life. Whether they’re pursuing their true passions and dreams or they’re stuck behind a desk working a job they detest- it is a universal human truth to seek what Joseph Campbell called the “rapture of being alive”. Our hearts know to listen to those whispers from The Universe(you know, the ones Oprah talks about)- but how often do we actually hear them? And how many of us have the courage to act when we do? Katie McKenna’s bravery to follow the scent in a new direction is thrilling and compelling to an audience.

I also want to tell the story of a woman with a non-conventional body in a way that doesn’t revolve around her weight or her struggles accepting her own body. Women of all body types are sexual beings. I feel their stories should be represented in media without having to focus on their struggles with their body or sexuality. 

Social Media has opened a Pandora’s Box that gives people too much access and zero direction. Our lives are bombarded with meaningless likes and posts and our souls ache for something real. Just as the reign of The Kardashians ushered in a generation of people who were “famous just for being famous”, Social Media has spawned their animal equivalents. In recent years dog have become some of the most profitable influencers on social media. Clawing their way to the top of elite social circles of money and fame. I aim to ask: Are Dog Stars and the world surrounding their fame any different from their Hollywood human equivalent? And what happens when a person with a conscious is introduced to this business?

And...I LOVE DOGS! WHO DOESN’T? 

Other Ways You Can Help

Okay, you aren't rich, I GET IT! You can barely pay your rent after all those cold brews. That's alright! If you can't contribute monetarily than PLEASE help me by posting a link to this campaign on your Facebook, Instagram, or Twitter. #AllEyesMatter
story_txt:
Why Are You Raising Money?
As an actor my future has more often than not been in the hands of other people. Let me give you my "favorite" example: Back in 2014 I booked a role opposite Amy Poehler in a film called The Nest (later retitled Sisters). Not only was this my first Hollywood studio film booking- I was going to get to act with one of my comedy idols. A day before the shoot date I was picked up and driven to Long Island for my fitting. There I saw the Executive Producer and we laughed together, I was fitted by the lovely costume department, took a few over enthusatic selfies in the trailer, and went back to NYC with a stupid grin of ecstasy plastered on my face. The next day I woke up extra early, worked out, drank a bunch of water, meditated, stretched, and imagined how great the day was going to be. Around 3PM, I gathered my things and headed out the door to meet the van going to set. As I turned the corner out of my building, my phone rang. It was a 212 number (which is ALWAYS exciting when you're an actor in NYC). I answered: "Hello?". A man's voice answered back "Hi Julia. This is Mike I'm calling from The Nest." "Hi Mike. I'm on the way to the van right now!" Mike paused and then he said "So, I know that this was on your list of fun things to do today...but unfortunately we had to cut your scene. I'm sorry". I acted like it wasn't a big deal, thanked Mike, and hung up. And just like that...everything sucked. This wouldn't be the first time I would be cut out of something. Or a huge National Network commercial I shot wouldn't air. Or I would be heart broken because I didn't book a life changing role. In fact, since then I've barely booked anything at all. As an actor- I don't fit into a box. So I decided enough was enough and I got back to my roots as a creator and wrote my television pilot Top Dog.  
What is Top Dog about?
Katie McKenna, a struggling plus-sized actress is smack in the middle of a spiritual crisis about pursuing a career in show business. When a series of kismet events propel her toward the chance at a more meaningful life working with dogs, she follows the scent to Los Angeles where she soon discovers she can’t shake the spotlight just yet because fate has led her into the lap of the largest & most successful talent agency...for dogs. 
The series follows Katie McKenna’s surprising rise in the company of Top Dog and the beginning of her journey in self discovery. It’s a story about enlightenment, about letting go and giving in, about self acceptance, about fighting ego, about what happens when you get to the TOP. It’s a story that asks “can you ever really get to the top?” and “what IS the top anyway?” 
So...What Do You Need From My Life?

Support (in the form of money). Have you ever had a friend email you a link to their independent film or video they put their heart & soul into but when you click on the link your heart sinks because it sounds and looks like it was shot on a first generation iPhone inside a garbage compactor? I REALLY care about the quality of my pilot Top Dog and I want to be taken seriously as an independent content creator. 
I shot 90% of the pilot using my own money I made bartending in a job I despise. But alas, I am now broke and am putting my pride aside to ask for help. In order to finish my pilot I need to shoot an elaborate opening scene which will require a budget for the following things. 
CREW (a professional Cinematographer, A professional Sound Operator, Camera Assistants, Productions Assistants, Etc.)
Locations, Lenses, Actors
Post Production

ulia Tokarz is a New York based actress, writer, director, & dog lover who has a BFA in Acting from LIU CW Post. Julia can be seen opposite comedian Chris D’Elia as his quirky assistant, Patty, in Heather Graham’s comedy Half Magic. story:
The Film

54 Blocks is a short, ten minute mockumentary following Tim Wilson and Danielle 'Daz' Brookes, two competitors in the sport of Mouth Jenga. Mouth Jenga is a fictitious sport where players play giant Jenga, but using only their mouths and greater facial regions to remove blocks. Throughout the film we meet townsfolk who are greatly invested in the sport, we witness the greatest rivalry the town has ever seen and we experience the associated dangers and controversies of this elite sport.

The production team for 54 Blocks is made up of UTS students completing their Bachelor of Communications in Media Arts Production.

The Cost

We are aiming to raise $4500 AUD in order to help us bring our story to life. This money will cover the costs of our locations, Jenga towers, props, costumes, catering, travel, festival costs and expenses for cast and crew.

We really appreciate any generous donation - big or small. As you will notice, we have some rewards designated to certain donation levels, so please have a look! It may make you... topple over! 

Other Ways You Can Help

We really appreciate any donation, however another way you can help our project is by sharing our project via the link or using the Indiegogo share tools. 

Share our IndieGoGo page, email your friends and family, post about us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc! 

Meet the cast!

Jade Ryan - Danielle 'Daz' Brookes

Jade is a film and television actor based in Sydney, Australia. She has trained at NIDA and AFTRS in Australia, and recently spent time studying at the John Rosenfeld Studio and the Margie Haber studio in LA, and the Stella Adler Studio of Acting in New York City. She is currently studying at The Actors Pulse in Sydney, being mentored by Hollywood Actor Grace Huang and is represented by Shine Talent Management. Jade has recently been cast in several lead roles in short films such as ‘Stalled’, ‘A Natural History of Dragons’ and ’54 Blocks’. She has also recently been awarded the honour of becoming a REELise Youth Ambassador.

Geoffrey Cordner - Tim Wilson

Geoffrey’s acting experience was accumulated through the mid to late 1990's when he appeared in a host of TV shows and commercials. Highlights of that period included an episode of Naked: Stories of Men starring a young Simon Baker, and a lead role in the Sydney International Airport Arrivals Terminal “Safety Tips for Travellers” video. In the last two years he returned to acting by playing Juror no. 8 in Gosford Theatre Company’s 2017 production of 12 Angry Men. Geoff’s screen credits over the last two years include lead roles in half a dozen short films including ‘The Disassociate’, featured in the 2017 Fringe Festival, a lead role in the music video for ‘Feel the Same’, a 2018 release by Sydney, the lead in a recent made-for-TV pilot with the working title ‘Anzac Bridge’ and more.

Belinda Delaney - Toni Somersby

Belinda is a highly trained and experienced actor, presenter and voice over artist with over 40 years experience. Belinda trained at WAAPA in the Musical Theatre course, has a BA and Graduate Diploma in Drama, studied for a Master of Theatre Arts (Directing) and is a qualified High School Drama/English teacher. Whilst at Uni, she won entry to the Australian National Young Playwrights Conference. In 1996 she was awarded a Newcastle Bicentenary Council Writing Grant which resulted in an historical play for young people. Her Screen experience includes speaking roles in dramas, re-enactments, corporate films and infomercials and as a presenter in various formats. She has won most drama and musical theatre events in the City of Sydney Eisteddfod and twice been nominated for acting awards.
 

Meet the crew!

Jonty Davies-Conyngham - Director

Jonty has been making films since he was 14 years old, originally making small movies with his friends for a YouTube channel. Since then he has gained experience as a director and cinematographer, working on short films, music videos, theatre-based productions and advertisements. ‘54 Blocks’ is Jonty’s first foray into the mockumentary genre, the film being his graduation project for his final year studying Media Arts and Production at the University of Technology Sydney. Jonty is looking forward to continuing to work on a large variety of productions as he moves further in his career.

Matt Ruki - Director of Photography

Matt is an aspiring filmmaker with experience in cinematography and camera work. He has previously worked on documentaries and short film productions, and several other projects with our Director, Jonty. In his final year of Media Arts and Production at UTS, he is looking forward to trying his hand at comedy, and specifically the mockumentary style short film ’54 Blocks’. Matt would also like it to be known that he is currently 1-0 against Jonty in their private competition of Mouth Jenga.

Lucy McDonald - Co-Producer / Production Manager

Lucy is an aspiring producer and assistant director. She began creating short comedy films from a young age and has since worked on numerous projects including short drama films, documentaries and commercial television shows. After completing her final year studying Media Arts and Production at the University of Technology Sydney, she hopes to continue to explore new mediums and genres of production. '54 Blocks' is Lucy's first project working with director Jonty Davies-Conyngham and is looking forward to being a part of the team to bring this amazing project to life.

Georgia Adler - Co-Producer / Assistant Director

Georgia is in her third and final year of a Bachelor of Communication (Media Arts and Production) at the University of Technology Sydney. She has had experience as a theatre-based Production Assistant for SCEGGS Darlinghurst, employed to work on ‘The Crucible’, ‘Putnam County Spelling Bee’ and ‘Not That Dream Again’. She has also been a Production Assistant and Intern for Heiress Films, working on the television show ‘Man Up’ that was broadcast on the ABC, in their social media department and website development. Georgia is currently undertaking an Internship in the Digital Media faculty at Network Ten, while completing her final semester of university.

Crystal Valdez - Production Designer

Crystal is a third year Media Arts and Production student at the University of Technology Sydney. ‘54 Blocks’ is her first time working as a Production Designer and Head of Art Department. She is also Media Head for Australia’s biggest street dance event and also represents ‘SIL Clothing Label’.

story:
RICOCHET: A film about one of the most celebrated trials of our time, and the international debate over immigration policy in the U.S.

Hi. I'm Jeff Adachi, the writer and producer of two award winning PBS feature documentary films  asking for your help to raise funds to complete the film.

RICOCHET is a feature length film about the tragic death of Kate Steinle. Kate was walking on Pier 14 in San Francisco with her father when a shot rang out. Seconds later, she was dead. An undocumented immigrant, Jose Garcia Zarate, was arrested and accused of murder. Within hours, then candidate Donald Trump used the case to justify his immigration policies, stating that the death of Steinle was caused by San Francisco's sanctuary city policies.  The trial of the case was one of the most watched and commented on trials of decade .

Matt Gonzalez, Chief Attorney of the San Francisco Public Defender's Office, is assigned the case and develops the evidence through a fascinating analysis of video evidence, forensic science and witnesses, including Garcia-Zarate.   Gonzalez is assisted by Francisco Ugarte, who heads the office's immigration unit, and the defense team.

The film is directed by Jeff Adachi, who has made several award winning films including "The Slanted Screen" and "You Don't Know Jack Soo," and edited by Emmy nominated Chihiro Wimbush ("Dogtown Redemption"). 

SFWeekly /Emily Wilson / Mon Apr 10th, 2017 

How You Can Help Me

I believe in this project and made a feature film that addresses the critical issues of our time, but I need your help. I need to raise $20,000 to complete editing the film. 

Please donate whatever you can to support our film and help make this film possible! Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • My name is Cam Richardson, Producer of the project. Being a passionate film student, I intend to fully provide this project with the best assistance possible. We hope to create a great project that will last for years to come.
  • This is a romantic comedy that touches on a point in our director's life that audiences will enjoy.
  • Contributors will help me us achieve stability for the project. Many things can occur in production and it's better to be in a safe place.

What We Need & What You Get

We will need about $900 for our project. Most of the money is for the reservation for a asylum location. The rest is for food, transportation, fees, miscellaneous, etc.

The Impact

  • This project touches light on experiences one faces in the LBGTQ community.
  • Me and Deja have both produced projects here at Towson University. We have collaborated on projects beforehand and that experience will help this project.
  • During my course of study at Towson University in the EMF ( Electronics, Film, and Media) program, my techniques and skills in screenwriting, editing, cinematography, and audio have increased drastically. I invite you to follow my team and I on this FILM journey . I have written a script for my Film 3 class and now I have to bring this film to life, with a real production crew, upscale equipment, trained actors, and a strict budget.

 

Risks & Challenges

  • This is a longer shoot. The film is intended to be 16 mins. I have gathered the best crew possible for the project. This will ensure things will be running smoother time wise. 
  • Floor Plan, Shot list, Overall Layout, Scheduling crew and actors conveniently will help 

ALSO

If you can't contribute remember you can always help spread the word through social media, friends, and family.

story:
Shane, his younger brother Ben, and his friends Keith and McKayla are trapped. They're trapped not only in the cycle of poverty, but also a town that's decaying around them. The circumstances of their environment become so suffocating, that it drives them to a very desperate plan: steal an ATM from a local motel, divide up the cash, and get out while they can.


With this film, we want to explore the extent to which the our environment shapes who we become. For too many, it's the inescapability of toxic circumstances that breed desperate and irrational action. In the case of our characters, their plan to steal an ATM isn't rooted in some sort of inherent evil or wrongness. Rather, it's the result of a desperate escapist fantasy that has left them detached from reality and rationality. 













Our official aim is $4,000, the minimum needed to bring An American Parable to life. 

Filmmaking is an expensive and exhausting process, even for the most passionate of creators. While we will be receiving camera and sound equipment from one of the top film institutions in the nation,  a film this special still requires a large number of other costs.

Authenticity of the environment is essential. Investing our budget in the right costuming, set design, and location rentals is integral to telling an honest and impactful story. Because this film takes place in rural communities, we will be leaving Chicago and shooting in trailer parks and motels across Illinois and Indiana. Additionally, we will be working with a cast and crew of over 30 dedicated (unpaid) volunteers. To thank them for their devotion to this project, it's our responsibility to make sure they're provided transportation and meals throughout our weekend of 12 hour shooting days. Here is a visual breakdown of our budget:



Every dollar we raise will go towards bringing this vision, these characters, and our passions to life.

In addition to the satisfaction of helping young artists pursue their dreams, we will be thanking you for your donation with one of our many perks:


Every contribution matters, monetarily or emotionally. If you're unable to donate to this film, we would still love to have you involved in any way possible. 

One of the best ways you can help us is by liking our Facebook page, and sharing this campaign on your social media! Show your support by spreading the word (and love) about this film :)

Our official aim is $4,000, the minimum needed to bring An American Parable to life. 
Filmmaking is an expensive and exhausting process, even for the most passionate of creators. While we will be receiving camera and sound equipment from one of the top film institutions in the nation,  a film this special still requires a large number of other costs.Authenticity of the environment is essential. Investing our budget in the right costuming, set design, and location rentals is integral to telling an honest and impactful story. Because this film takes place in rural communities, we will be leaving Chicago and shooting in trailer parks and motels across Illinois and Indiana. Additionally, we will be working with a cast and crew of over 30 dedicated (unpaid) volunteers. To thank them for their devotion to this project, it's our responsibility to make sure they're provided transportation and meals throughout our weekend of 12 hour shooting days. Here is a visual breakdown of our budget:Every dollar we raise will go towards bringing this vision, these characters, and our passions to life.

In addition to the satisfaction of helping young artists pursue their dreams, we will be thanking you for your donation with one of our many perks:



Every contribution matters, monetarily or emotionally. If you're unable to donate to this film, we would still love to have you involved in any way possible. One of the best ways you can help us is by liking our Facebook page, and sharing this campaign on your social media! Show your support by spreading the word (and love) about this film :)

story:
I was inspired by this quote 

“Why do you go away? So that you can come back. So that you can see the place you came from with new eyes and extra colours. And the people there see you differently, too. Coming back to where you started is not the same as never leaving.” Terry Pratchett, A Hat Full of Sky

The last few years has seen lots of discussion about immigration. Notions of 'nationhood' and 'Britishness' are hotly debated in the media, as well as the scandal faced by the Windrush generation, who were mostly invited to the UK. Now with many of them retiring, they face choices about where to spend the rest of their lives. Are they British enough to stay or can they ever really go 'home'?

I'm an independent filmmaker and budding historian. I originally started as a writer, but soon realised it was going to difficult to tell the stories I wanted to, unless I unskilled and learned about filmmaking. My stories are uplifting, positive and about what connects us as human beings. 

Reflecting on my Jamaican roots and traditions, my characters ultimately must learn that as long as life continues, there is hope. I write about young characters a lot because I feel it's  a  difficult time to grow up in this social media age, and separating from the 'tribe' is part of the process of maturing. I try to live with compassion, and acceptance, and want to reflect those qualities in my work - as well as being entertaining. I used to do comedy so I can tell jokes!

Proper Charlie presents a snapshot of present day UK,  as an intergenerational discourse about belonging takes place, together with an exploration of these themes. 

 

Synopsis

A retired man's plan to sail back to the Caribbean is scuppered, and through his seafaring adventure, he comes full circle, as he learns home is where the heart is.

 

How can you help?

Filming is cheaper than it's ever been, but some things are still expensive. About 50% of Proper Charlie is set on a boat, and we need to use a special set and have crew experienced on these kind of shoots. The boat is an important part of the story.

I'm raising funds to do a test shoot. I need to scope out the location and the boat, and produce a sizzle reel to show the look and feel of the feature. 

I need 9k to do it properly. This will enable me to then attach a great character actor, and help to  raise the rest of the production costs, which is  around 1M.  

I have experience of making a feature film- Nine Nights, and bringing it in on time and on budget. 

You can find out more about Nine Nights here - www.ninenightsfilm.com. It is due to be distributed late 2020 on all platforms worldwide. It also won a major award. 

The trailer is here https://vimeo.com/366297862

Proper Charlie is a real adventure story with themes that are relatable. It's a portrayal of a black family that you don't often see on screen, and it's important to counter some of the prevailing negative representations out there. Plus it's warm, funny and will be beautifully shot. 

It will be at least two years until the film is finished, so I can't offer any DVD's etc right now, (do people still play them?) but I am open to people wanting to be supporting artists in the film, post Covid of course.

Okay I think that's it. Please consider contributing. It's tough out there at this time, so I totally understand if you can't. You can also follow me on veemack1 and ninenightsfilm on twitter.  

Thanks for reading:)

Veronica

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • We are Isaiah and Aaron, the co-creators of an award-winning short film Frank and Us that has been receiving an amazing amount of attention on short content streaming channels. 
  • The viewers have spoken and WE HAVE NO CHOICE BUT TO BRING CHAPTER 2 TO LIFE! We're thrilled by the responses and overly excited to jump back into this world that we took a year to create. 
  • Frank and Us is the story of a drifter who, after losing his family to a near apocalyptic alien invasion, takes solace in an abandoned town. At the peak of Frank going stir crazy, he's visited by other drifters that turn his world upside down. Chapter 2 dives right into the wasteland like world and explores Frank's incapability of living with others as he travels the desolate desert for his friend Sam. The action starts right away with an up close interaction with the aliens, after that Frank has to defend a weak family from a pack of blood-thirty raiders who depict the true cruelty that the world has become. 

 

  • We've wanted to make this film the second we finished the first film but like most indie artists, we ran out of money. However, that didn't stop us from writing and creating the world Frank lives in. We honed in on a 12 part TV series that we're currently shopping around the industry. With the current condition of the film industry and the impact the pandemic is having on it, TV series are getting stuck in creative purgatory so we said... "screw this" let's do it ourselves and have some fun and let's bring other creatives or post-apoc enthusiasts along on the ride. Your contribution means the world to us because we'll finally be able to create the world we've been dreaming about for almost 2 years now. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • We're looking for $4500 to revamp this film. Some might say... but that's nothing? It's not much but we don't need full funding of the film which will end up being $10K, we're going to cover half on our own but we do need help with the rest. We need this money to permit our shoot at a desert location, production design, produce an alien costume, attach a professional make-up artist so that it doesn't look campy. 
  • What type of perks do you get from your investment?
    • $10 gets you a shout out on our social medias. We're not influencers or anything but we do have a tight crew of people that love to see other people helping other artists so hey maybe your shout out will attract someone to welcome you onto another project. 
    • $25 gets you a poster
    • $50 - Early access to watching the film. If we do an intimate screening YOU'RE INVITED. Trust us... it'll be one hell of a night. 
    • $100 gets you a Frank and Us T-Shirt
    • $200 lands you an associate producer title in the credits and on IMDB
    • $500 Mike Ferguson himself is going to give you a personal TATTOO
    • $750 lands you a scene in the film where Mike kills you. And you get one line of dialogue. This is only open to one person for obvious reasons haha. 
    • $1000 gets you the big Executive Producer credit

Risks & Challenges

  • Fortunately we keep our crew very tight so it'll be a skeleton operation but we still need to adhere to Covid protocols for everyones safety. That means testing beforehand, hiring a safety monitor, building cleaning stations, and providing hand sanitizers. 
  • And of course with having a small crew comes people wearing multiple hats. The director will more than likely be the script supervisor, the gaffer and damn... possibly the back-up safety coordinator. That's okay though, we've done this before and sometimes creating a team-building environment is one of the best takeaways from shooting a film.

story:
(In english below)


El Proyecto Essentia


Essential es un documental sobre la musica electrónica en Sudamérica, más precisamente Perú, Chile, Argentina y Uruguay pensado, realizado y conceptualizado por Marilou Vallès y Rodrigo Posada. 

El proyecto nace en Lima en 2016 de nuestra curiosidad a aprender más sobre el movimiento de la escena en el continente. Después de haber documentado durante unos años la escena peruana con nuestra revista online Datexeus, quisimos ampliar el espectro hacía el continente para entender más y mejor la efervescencia de estas diferentes escenas. 

En diciembre 2017 partimos con 2 cámaras, una Kombi VW para un viaje de dos años y medio de rodaje. Atravesamos Peru, Chile, Argentina y Uruguay. Invertimos todos nuestros ahorros para realizar este sueño. En 2 años y medio, realizamos más de 60 entrevistas en más de 10 ciudades. 
 






 

 

 

Nuestra meta principal fue salir a conocer a la gente involucrada en la escena más independiente de esas diferentes ciudades : Lima y Cuzco (Perú), Arica, Iquique, Valparaiso, Santiago, Concepción y Puerto Montt (Chile), Rosario y Buenos Aires (Argentina) & Montevideo (Uruguay). Djs, productores, promotores, dueños de locales, organizadores de festivales y eventos. Personas y sus iniciativas nacidas por puro amor al arte y a la música. Nuestra intención fue presentar retratos de personas de diferentes generaciones y ámbitos musicales para dar de conocer un espéctro lo más amplio posible así como armar diálogos sobre diferentes temáticas. Descubrimos problemáticas pero también filosofías propias a cada país y de cada entrevista salíamos con más preguntas y inquietudes. 

Lo mas bonito de esta aventura fue de lejos el aspecto humano y su riqueza. Compartir con gente maravillosa que siempre nos recibieron con pura buena vibra en su ciudad, casa o estudio y gracias a quién nos sentimos cada día más apoyados y legítimos a emprender esta búsqueda. Descubrimos ciudades hirviendo de música, arte, lucha, cultura y contracultura.  Experimentamos también la música electrónica en su versión más pura, independiente y rebelde, más política. 

Una cultura alternativa que responde a un sistema que todavía la estigmatiza demasiado. Una lucha perpetua para hacer reconocer su arte como cultura y no solamente como un entretenimiento. 
 


Sinopsis
 

Essentia se inspira en la búsqueda por conocer las escenas de la música electrónica independiente en el Perú, Chile, Uruguay y Argentina encontrándose con distintas perspectivas en cuanto a las motivaciones de gestionar cultura,  dejando en común en todas ellas;  el aspecto comunitario de entablar relaciones entre personas  que quieren vivir en una sociedad mejor.

Y es la música un estímulo para el alma que funciona como un motor para esas comunidades en su lado más puro,  gestando el desarrollo de nuevos espacios de expresión cultural, la cual, en muchos casos está cargada de connotaciones políticas que van en contra  de los esquemas establecidos y de la mercantilizada industria musical.

Este documental propone discusiones y diferentes enfoques sobre el artista, su relación con la música y su convivencia con el parámetro comercial. Invita a cuestionarnos cómo el arte puede subsistir mediante intereses económicos, manteniendo su carácter auténtico / subjetivo sin que este se diluya en el tiempo o se vea sacrificado por lo primero.

¿Se debe estar sujetos a las tendencias musicales impuestas por la industria para el desarrollo de producciones, o se debe apostar por el fuego, intuitivo y creativo del artista?¿Qué relación guardan las escenas de éstos países entre ellas?  ¿Cómo hacer valorar éste movimiento para que adquiera características más culturales y que deje de ser visto como medio de mero entretenimiento?


Dónde estamos y lo que necesitamos

 

Auto producimos todo el proceso y asumimos todos los gastos que representaron esos años en la carretera. Ahora, estamos en el hermoso proceso de editarlo y estamos en la fase final. Tenemos muchas ganas de poder compartir todo esta enseñanza con el publico. Mariano, un gran DJ de Rosario, Argentina, nos decía que para él hacer discos es como hacerle un regalo a la música, una retribución a todo lo bonito que nos da en la vida. Nos parece una manera muy bonita de ver la cosa, y pensamos igual para el documental. Dejar algo concreto, un objeto visual y sonoro, un regalo para la escena.

Si lees estas palabras hoy, es que necesitamos su apoyo para finalizar este proyecto.  Los fondos que podremos recaudar por este medio nos ayudaran a asumir los gastos de :

  • Post-producción : Mezcla de sonido profesional, etalonnage, motion graphic y subtítulos.

  • Promoción : Operación de promoción digital, fees de presentación a festivales, viajes para asistir a presentaciones y proyecciones. 

  • Producción de los DVDs y de la banda original en formato Vinilo y CD. 

 

Otras maneras en cuales puedes apoyar el proyecto

 

Estamos consciente que no todos podemos apoyar de la misma manera, pero si te gustó el proyecto, compartirlo, hablar de ello a tus amigos o artistas que podrían ser interesados...  Es gratis y puede hacer mucho! :)



http://www.facebook.com/EssentiaDocumentary
http://www.instagram.com/EssentiaDocumentary

 

///////////////////////////////////////////////// ENGLISH  ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////

 

Essentia project


Essential is a documentary about electronic music in South America, more precisely Peru, Chile, Argentina and Uruguay made and conceptualized by Marilou Vallès and Rodrigo Posada.

The project was born in Lima in 2016 from our curiosity to learn more about the movement of the scene in the continent. After having documented the Peruvian scene for a few years with our online magazine Datexeus, we wanted to broaden the spectrum towards the continent to understand more and better the effervescence of these different scenes.

In December 2017 we left with 2 cameras, a VW Kombi for a trip of two and a half years of shooting. We go through Peru, Chile, Argentina and Uruguay. We invested all of our savings to realize this dream. In 2 and a half years, we conducted more than 60 interviews in more than 10 cities.

Our main goal was to get to know the people involved in the most independent scene in these different cities: Lima and Cuzco (Peru), Arica, Iquique, Valparaiso, Santiago, Concepción and Puerto Montt (Chile), Rosario and Buenos Aires (Argentina) & Montevideo, Uruguay). Djs, producers, promoters, venue owners, festival and event organizers. People and their initiatives born out of pure love of art and music. Our intention was to present portraits of people of different generations and musical fields to make a spectrum as wide as possible known as well as to put together dialogues on different topics. We discovered problems but also philosophies specific to each country and from each interview we came out with more questions and concerns.

The most beautiful thing about this adventure was by far the human aspect and its wealth. Share with wonderful people who always received us with pure good vibes in their city, home or studio and thanks to whom we feel more supported and legitimate every day to undertake this search. We discover cities seething with music, art, struggle, culture and counterculture. We also experience electronic music in its purest, most independent and rebellious, more political version.

An alternative culture that responds to a system that still stigmatizes it too much. A perpetual struggle to make their art recognized as culture and not just as entertainment.
 


Synospis
 

Essentia is inspired by the search to know the scenes of independent electronic music in Peru, Chile, Uruguay and Argentina, finding different perspectives regarding the motivations of managing culture, leaving in common in all of them; the community aspect of building relationships between people who want to live in a better society.

And music is a stimulus for the soul that works as an engine for these communities in their purest side, gestating the development of new spaces for cultural expression, which, in many cases, is loaded with political connotations that go against the established schemes and the commodified music industry.

This documentary proposes discussions and different approaches about the artist, his relationship with music and his coexistence with the commercial parameter. It invites us to question how art can subsist through economic interests, maintaining its authentic / subjective character without this being diluted over time or being sacrificed for the former.

Should we be subject to the musical trends imposed by the industry for the development of productions, or should we bet on the fire, intuitive and creative of the artist? What relationship do the scenes of these countries have between them? How can this movement be valued so that it acquires more cultural characteristics and stops being seen as a means of mere entertainment?

 

Where we are and what we need


We self-produced the whole process and we assumed all the expenses that those years on the road represented. Now, we are in the beautiful process of editing it and we are in the final phase. We really want to share all this teaching with the public. Mariano, a great DJ from Rosario, Argentina, told us that for him making records is like giving music a gift, a reward for all the beauty that it gives us in life. It seems like a very nice way of looking at it, and we think the same for the documentary. Leave something concrete, a visual and sound object, a gift for the scene.

If you read these words today, it is because we need your support to finish this project. The funds that we can collect through this means will help us to assume the expenses of:

  • Post-production: Mix of professional sound, etalonnage, motion graphic and subtitles.

  • Promotion: Digital promotion operation, festival presentation fees, trips to attend presentations and screenings.

  • Production of the DVDs and the original band in Vinyl and CD format.

 


Other ways you can support the project


We are aware that we cannot all support in the same way, but if you liked the project, share it, talk about it to your friends or artists who might be interested ... It's free and it can do a lot! :)

http://www.facebook.com/EssentiaDocumentary
http://www.instagram.com/EssentiaDocumentary
