Si lees estas palabras hoy, es que necesitamos su apoyo para finalizar este proyecto.  Los fondos que podremos recaudar por este medio nos ayudaran a asumir los gastos de :

Post-producción : Mezcla de sonido profesional, etalonnage, motion graphic y subtítulos.
Promoción : Operación de promoción digital, fees de presentación a festivales, viajes para asistir a presentaciones y proyecciones. 
Producción de los DVDs y de la banda original en formato Vinilo y CD. 

 

Otras maneras en cuales puedes apoyar el proyecto
 
Estamos consciente que no todos podemos apoyar de la misma manera, pero si te gustó el proyecto, compartirlo, hablar de ello a tus amigos o artistas que podrían ser interesados...  Es gratis y puede hacer mucho! :)http://www.facebook.com/EssentiaDocumentaryhttp://www.instagram.com/EssentiaDocumentary
 
///////////////////////////////////////////////// ENGLISH  ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
 
Essentia project
Essential is a documentary about electronic music in South America, more precisely Peru, Chile, Argentina and Uruguay made and conceptualized by Marilou Vallès and Rodrigo Posada.
The project was born in Lima in 2016 from our curiosity to learn more about the movement of the scene in the continent. After having documented the Peruvian scene for a few years with our online magazine Datexeus, we wanted to broaden the spectrum towards the continent to understand more and better the effervescence of these different scenes.
In December 2017 we left with 2 cameras, a VW Kombi for a trip of two and a half years of shooting. We go through Peru, Chile, Argentina and Uruguay. We invested all of our savings to realize this dream. In 2 and a half years, we conducted more than 60 interviews in more than 10 cities.
Our main goal was to get to know the people involved in the most independent scene in these different cities: Lima and Cuzco (Peru), Arica, Iquique, Valparaiso, Santiago, Concepción and Puerto Montt (Chile), Rosario and Buenos Aires (Argentina) & Montevideo, Uruguay). Djs, producers, promoters, venue owners, festival and event organizers. People and their initiatives born out of pure love of art and music. Our intention was to present portraits of people of different generations and musical fields to make a spectrum as wide as possible known as well as to put together dialogues on different topics. We discovered problems but also philosophies specific to each country and from each interview we came out with more questions and concerns.
The most beautiful thing about this adventure was by far the human aspect and its wealth. Share with wonderful people who always received us with pure good vibes in their city, home or studio and thanks to whom we feel more supported and legitimate every day to undertake this search. We discover cities seething with music, art, struggle, culture and counterculture. We also experience electronic music in its purest, most independent and rebellious, more political version.
An alternative culture that responds to a system that still stigmatizes it too much. A perpetual struggle to make their art recognized as culture and not just as entertainment. 


Synospis 
Essentia is inspired by the search to know the scenes of independent electronic music in Peru, Chile, Uruguay and Argentina, finding different perspectives regarding the motivations of managing culture, leaving in common in all of them; the community aspect of building relationships between people who want to live in a better society.
And music is a stimulus for the soul that works as an engine for these communities in their purest side, gestating the development of new spaces for cultural expression, which, in many cases, is loaded with political connotations that go against the established schemes and the commodified music industry.
This documentary proposes discussions and different approaches about the artist, his relationship with music and his coexistence with the commercial parameter. It invites us to question how art can subsist through economic interests, maintaining its authentic / subjective character without this being diluted over time or being sacrificed for the former.
Should we be subject to the musical trends imposed by the industry for the development of productions, or should we bet on the fire, intuitive and creative of the artist? What relationship do the scenes of these countries have between them? How can this movement be valued so that it acquires more cultural characteristics and stops being seen as a means of mere entertainment?
 
Where we are and what we need
We self-produced the whole process and we assumed all the expenses that those years on the road represented. Now, we are in the beautiful process of editing it and we are in the final phase. We really want to share all this teaching with the public. Mariano, a great DJ from Rosario, Argentina, told us that for him making records is like giving music a gift, a reward for all the beauty that it gives us in life. It seems like a very nice way of looking at it, and we think the same for the documentary. Leave something concrete, a visual and sound object, a gift for the scene.
If you read these words today, it is because we need your support to finish this project. The funds that we can collect through this means will help us to assume the expenses of:

Post-production: Mix of professional sound, etalonnage, motion graphic and subtitles.
Promotion: Digital promotion operation, festival presentation fees, trips to attend presentations and screenings.
Production of the DVDs and the original band in Vinyl and CD format.

 


Other ways you can support the project
We are aware that we cannot all support in the same way, but if you liked the project, share it, talk about it to your friends or artists who might be interested ... It's free and it can do a lot! :)
http://www.facebook.com/EssentiaDocumentaryhttp://www.instagram.com/EssentiaDocumentary

story:
I've been writing screenplays for over twenty years.  More recently, I've realized that in order to see my works actually make it to screen, becoming a filmmaker is just as crucial as creating the story. 

Of course, filmmaking is a collaborative art form and I've been fortunate enough to find talented crew and cast for this short film project.

About ten months ago, I pitched this project to my fellow filmmakers at Scary Cow, a filmmaking organization based in the SF bay area.  For the past 8 months, it's been on hold, for obvious reasons.  When another fellow filmmaker decided to shoot a short film with a Covid Safety officer on set I felt inspired to move ahead with my project.

The story is about a woman who has mysterious culinary skills that she uses to her advantage depending on the situation.  I'm targeting a running time of approximately 18 minutes.

My fundraising goal is $2500.  Donations will help me with props, location rentals, meals for crew, safety/Covid prevention measures, insurance, etc.  

Ultimately, I will try to get the completed film into a short film festival(s).  After this period, I will post the short film on Vimeo for those who have contributed towards the project.

Anyone interested in viewing my first film, Give Me Danger, feel free to contact me for the Vimeo password.

Screenwriting and filmmaking are my creative outlet and you would be greatly impacting my life with a contribution.  I hope that this short film will entertain and inspire others to create their own works of art.

And please let everybody know about my Indiegogo Campaign.  Thanks!!

story:
Our Story Thus Far

Hello there!  Thank you for checking out our campaign, we hope that you can be the difference in making this dream a reality.

We're a group of students/friends in Greeley, CO (Not so lovingly referred to as Cowtown). When we started working on 'Cowtown' nearly half a year ago we were filled with a lot of ambition and we still are!  However, we realized early on that we wouldn't be able to make this film without some sort of budget.   It took a long time to set that budget and this campaign in order, but now we're rearing to go!  During the course of the campaign we'll getting the last pieces in place (Filling out spaller roles, a readthrough, character work etc.).  With your help by the end of that time we'll have the finances we need to get rolling on production.   

What We Need and What You Get

Our Overall goal is $8000, this can be divided down to:

- $5000 For Camera + Lense Rental

- $2000 For Locations + Props

- $1000 For Audio + Recording Equipment

The real question is, what happens if we don't reach our goal?  Where does the money go?  

Our priorities, if we don't hit our goal, are the basics.  A camera, some sound gear, and locations.  If we have those we can make the movie.  Of course we don't WANT to do it this way.  We want to be able to create a product that does the story justice.   But, if there's no other choice, we'll make do.  

Why Cowtown?

3 Reasons:

1.  Cowtown is a fresh take on the classic, high school, coming of age story.  While the film takes place in a gritty reality, there is always a scent of the mystical in the air.  Cowtown isn't quite what it seems.

2.  The film deals with topics of classism, homophobia, and alienation.  Overall it has a lot to say about the world as it is now.

3.  The incredible talent on board!  Every actor is perfect for their role and the people behind the scenes are all future masters of their craft.  I (Nik Blatt the Writer/Director of the film) do not say this lightly.

Team 

Nik Blatt (Writer/Director/Score/John) is very excited to finally be able to share 'Cowtown' with the world!  It's been a long but rewarding process.  Although he's been writing for a long time this is first feature and it's the first project he's felt he needed to share.  He's acted in the Northern Colorado area for the past few years and has also worked in Boulder and Denver.  He's grateful for the wonderful cast and crew that have put up with his "artistic process" and he hopes that you support the campaign!

Chris Martin (Jamie) is a local actor currently studying at the University of Northern Colorado. He has performed in theatre in the Denver area including roles with Inspire Creative, Stage Left Productions, and Performance Now theatre company. He has also acted in short films for Colorado Film School as well as an independent TV pilot. 

Lydia Kanous (Hope) is a Junior acting major at UNC.  She is excited to make her film debut among such amazing artists.  Since the beginning of Covid-19 Lydia has wanted to keep making art, and although the art world has changed this talented group has come together to make something beautiful.  Please donate and share!

Wil Francis (Cinematographer) is an aspiring Photographer and Cinematographer. He is currently attending the Colorado Film School. This is his first feature film and he couldn’t be more excited to be working with such a talented cast and crew.  He thinks this story has the potential to be something really special.Sophia Shafiuzzaman (Production Manager) is a senior Design and Technology major with an emphasis is Stage management, as well as a Communication Studies major. Sophia is excited to work as a PM for 'Cowtown'. This is her first film credit. She has previously worked as a stage manager for The Book of Will & the 2019 Spring One Acts at UNC; her previous assistant stage manager credits would include, The Cherry Orchard at UNC, Lobby Hero, and I Loved, I Lost, I Made Spaghetti at UNC’s Little Theatre of the Rockies. 

 

And Many More!

Some Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! 

- Share this campaign on social media

- Tell your friends

- Tell strangers

Help work on the project!  If you know people on the production or just think you could be of some use feel free to email us at CowtownOfficial@gmail.com.  At the time of this Campaign going live we are looking for audio people, grips, and people to fill a few small roles as well as the older characters!

story:
Short Summary

 

  • Je suis Ornella Cindy EBOKO, CEO de FRIKAKIDZ TV (chaine africaine de dessins animés) et la productrice du film d'animation "LES MIROIRS DE KAMA". Maman d'une petite fille, je me suis très vite rendue compte du manque de représentations et valorisation de personnages à la peau foncée ou albinos dans les dessins animés.
  • Pour ce film, nous nous sommes inspirés d’énormément de cultures africaines. Que ce soit les noms des personnages, les costumes, les symboles, les masques, les habitations, les coutumes...

  • C’est la raison pour laquelle nous invitons tout le monde à participer à la levée de fond pour la réalisation de ce long métrage d’animation. C’est notre histoire à tous, elle n’a pas de nationalité, elle est africaine

What We Need & What You Get

  • Nous vous tiendrons informés de toutes les étapes et bien évidement restons ouverts à vos suggestions et connaissances.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

And that's all there is to it.

What We Need & What You Get

story:
Overview

Love's Best Habit is an original short film created by Genevieve Simon, Jimmy Fay and Lilian Wouters.

[Film Website]   [Instagram]

Visit our Instagram @lovesbesthabit_film for updates on our production process, screenings and ticket information and soon to be on a streaming service. We started having initial meetings for this project in January with filming expected to take place in May. 

The film has also the intention to be on the festival circuit in 2022! 

Thank you so much for your support, it is deeply appreciated. 

For more background information to the production, read on or visit our website www.lovesbesthabitfilm.com

LOVE’S BEST HABIT -  France, 1700s. Charlotte and Marie, two novices in love, must decide whether to remain at the convent or escape to the city. A fight about their future tears the fabric of reality, as they grapple with the harder truth that you cannot change the ones you love. 


Lilian Wouters (Actor/Producer) found herself feeling extremely helpless as an actor during Covid/Quarantine, she found herself daydreaming about what her perfect, ideal project could be…

She says “[co-star] Meg Evans and I always had incredible chemistry during our time in graduate school at UC Irvine and she was the first person to pop into my head to create a universe with/around. Something I ask myself quite frequently in my work is, "What is the least we can do". I find it can help you define your project and trim the fat, so to speak. We needed to keep it simple. A simple story for just two actors” 

So, I started daydreaming, and one of the most exciting elements that I navigated towards was Shakespeare's sonnets. How can we tell a story between these two actors, involving sonnets, chemistry, and the tools we have at our disposal?

But first, I needed a team and I needed support. Kirsten Dwyer has been a good friend of mine through High School, Community College, and even was a huge rock of support during the one year I braved the East Coast. She serendipitously had moved to California in December of 2020 and, very generously hopped on board with energy, enthusiasm, and the know-how to produce this film. 

Now I had a very specific story forming in my head, that meant I needed a writer who was willing to take these ideas and say "Yes AND-". Genevieve Simon (Co-writer) is one of my favorite creators of universes and the first person I thought of that might be willing to indulge my fantasies. We had an initial meeting and as it was very clear we were leaning towards a queer story, Genevieve recommended bringing in Jim Fay (co-writer) to help tell this story. And thus, a dream team was born.

Up until now, our core team has been contributing their time and expertise without compensation and we have been inviting a select group of people to support and sponsor the production -- but now we are in need of your help. 

We have set our goal at $6,000, which when combined with other contributions is enough to get us to our goal, allowing us to make this a truly independent film. If you are donating from the U.S., remember that your contribution is tax-deductible.

Your contributions will help pay for:

  • Additional technical crew and equipment
  • Production support staff
  • Some travel and accommodation
  • Post-production services like editing facilities, color correction, and sound mixing

We expect there will be 3 days of filming with $1000 needed for each day. Money will also be needed for food, lodging, and travel for our crew of 6 in addition to hiring out for post-production.

 

As a thank you for your contributions, our creative team brings us loads of diverse offerings; Fitzmaurice Voicework Workshops/ private lessons, and yoga sessions. We are offering a number of ways to see the film including downloads and streaming and the hopes for it to join the festival circuit. 

An Associate Producer credit is also available, but please note there is only room for 2 of these production credits.

And, of course, if you just want to donate, IndieGoGo allows you to contribute any amount you like.

Whatever your preference, please do contribute whatever you can and most importantly share our campaign with your friends and followers to help spread the word! 


 

LILIAN WOUTERS: Actor, creator, executive producer 

Lilian was born and raised in California and considers herself a true California Spirit. She recently graduated from the University of California, Irvine's MFA program with her degree in Acting! Lilian has a huge passion for sonnets and is excited to bring that inspiration to this peace. When not pursuing a career in film, television, and voice-over, Lilian enjoys crocheting and hanging out with her two cats, Rudy and DeeDee. www.lilianwouters.com

MEG EVANS: Actor

Meg Evans is a Los Angeles-based actor and physical theatre artist. Credits include Macbeth (Lady Macbeth), The Survival Project directed by Mihai Maniutiu and Andrea Gavriliu, Cie. Willi Dorner’s Bodies in Urban Spaces (Dublin, Ireland) and multiple seasons as a company member of the New Swan Shakespeare Festival. Lover of movement, mindbody practices and fitness. Meg holds a Bachelor of Arts from Brandeis University, an MPhil from Trinity College Dublin, and an MFA in Acting from the University of California, Irvine. www.itsmegevans.com

RACHELLE DART: Director 

Rachelle Dart is a theatre maker, traditional storyteller, teaching artist and Sonoran Desert dweller. She earned a Bachelors in Theatre with a Concentration in Acting from Arizona State University and is a certified teacher of Fitzmaurice Voicework®. An Advanced Actor Combatant with the Society of American Fight Directors she is passionate about safe stage combat in education and performance. She apprenticed in the craft of storytelling with Irish storyteller Liz Weir, MBE.

GENEVIEVE SIMON: writer 

Genevieve Simon’s work has been produced and developed in New York at The Tank, Corkscrew Theatre Festival, The People’s Improv Theatre, Pete’s Candy Store, and The HIVE. Regionally, her work has been seen at Actors Theatre of Louisville, PortFringe Festival, and Cincinnati Fringe Festival. Awards: Critic’s Pick, Producer’s Pick of the Fringe (Cincinnati Fringe 2017). New Georges Affiliated Artist. www.genevieve-simon.com

JIM FAY: writer

Jimmy Fay is a poet, dramatic writer and performer. Their poetry has appeared in Panoplyzine, GASHER Journal and more. Their recent film Mosquito, which they wrote and starred in, is currently making its way through the festival circuit including Portland International Film Festival and Los Angeles International Film Festival. They are passionate about queer history and queer future.

KIRSTEN DWYER: producer; digital media

 Having been friends with Lilian Wouters (Creator & Executive Producer) for over 15 years, Kirsten Dwyer (Producer) is honored to be able to help bring this production to the big screen, working with a group of talented passionate women. Kirsten brings over 10 years of film, television, and media experience having worked in New York, San Francisco and Los Angeles with 9 Clouds Films, foolsFURY Theater, and the Erika Chong Shuch Performance Project. She is a proud member of  SAG-AFTRA and New York Women in Film and Television -- www.KirstenDwyer.com. 

OTHER WAYS TO SUPPORT! 

Spread the word! Share this crowd-funding effort, tell your family, friends and colleagues and connect via social media pages. Like, follow and share www.lovesbesthabitfilm.com |  Instagram

She earned a Bachelors in Theatre with a Concentration in Acting from Arizona State University and is a certified teacher of Fitzmaurice Voicework®. An Advanced Actor Combatant with the Society of American Fight Directors she is passionate about safe stage combat in education and performance. She apprenticed in the craft of storytelling with Irish storyteller Liz Weir, MBE.GENEVIEVE SIMON: writer Genevieve Simon’s work has been produced and developed in New York at The Tank, Corkscrew Theatre Festival, The People’s Improv Theatre, Pete’s Candy Store, and The HIVE. Regionally, her work has been seen at Actors Theatre of Louisville, PortFringe Festival, and Cincinnati Fringe Festival. Awards: Critic’s Pick, Producer’s Pick of the Fringe (Cincinnati Fringe 2017). New Georges Affiliated Artist. www.genevieve-simon.comJIM FAY: writerJimmy Fay is a poet, dramatic writer and performer. Their poetry has appeared in Panoplyzine, GASHER Journal and more. Their recent film Mosquito, which they wrote and starred in, is currently making its way through the festival circuit including Portland International Film Festival and Los Angeles International Film Festival. They are passionate about queer history and queer future.KIRSTEN DWYER: producer; digital media Having been friends with Lilian Wouters (Creator & Executive Producer) for over 15 years, Kirsten Dwyer (Producer) is honored to be able to help bring this production to the big screen, working with a group of talented passionate women. Kirsten brings over 10 years of film, television, and media experience having worked in New York, San Francisco and Los Angeles with 9 Clouds Films, foolsFURY Theater, and the Erika Chong Shuch Performance Project. She is a proud member of  SAG-AFTRA and New York Women in Film and Television -- www.KirstenDwyer.com. OTHER WAYS TO SUPPORT! Spread the word! Share this crowd-funding effort, tell your family, friends and colleagues and connect via social media pages. Like, follow and share www.lovesbesthabitfilm.com |  Instagram

story:
As an anxious, but low-maintenance child, 7-year-old Charlie finds herself caught in the crossfire of a parental war zone. Due to her mom being a cam girl and father clutching onto his insecurities, she finds it hard to see where she is standing in such a big world. With the help of the plastic flamingos flocking her front yard and a new perspective, Charlie is able to take comfort through the stress of her parent’s inevitable separation.

Pink Flamingos was inspired by my time spent in my childhood home in Kentucky this past spring. It was the start of the pandemic and things honestly felt hopeless. I never thought when I left for college I would be right back in my room thats walls aged alongside me. I decided to go for a bike ride in my neighborhood and it was a few streets up that I saw it- a little girl playing hopscotch in front of her house. Her mom was on the porch talking into her cellphone clearly distraught. Yet, the girl was in her own world, unphased by everything that surrounded her. This visual sparked an interest to explore what truly goes on both from inside and outside a family's home. As I continued to peddle up the street, I saw a neighbor's front lawn filled with these godly pink plastic flamingos... and the story started to form from there.

Pink Flamingos is a short film that relies heavily upon camera, production design, and locations. With your contribution, we will be able to provide our crew with the right materials and equipment to achieve our desired vision. In order to support Charlie’s outlook on her parent’s relationship, a particular camera package has been put together to express her distinct visual language on screen. Production design will need to reconstruct the ins and outs of Charlie’s house, which establishes the foundation of the story. In order for production design to accomplish this, we have to find the right structure for them to explore the space. With your help and support, we will be able to deliver a story that seeks to be told to a larger audience.

Due to the ongoing Pandemic, our top priority is to ensure the safety of our cast and crew. That being said, certified masks, gloves, wipes, hand sanitizer, cleaning supplies, and organized sanitary stations are a must. We are passionate about making a story that will reach viewers beyond the screen, but in order to do that, we need to make sure we are safe off screen. 

Pink Flamingos calls attention to mental health and anxiety from the early stages of childhood. A topic as important as this has rarely been explored from a child’s perspective on screen. Our hopes in sharing Charlie’s story is to open up a conversation of how an unhealthy environment and disproportionate levels of stress can affect one’s mental health later in life. We aim to show that there is hope during a time when life feels like it is shifting under our feet, even in the most unexpected places. We are grateful for your support and aid in this ambitious project, and look forward to delivering a film that speaks volumes to young children struggling with mental health everywhere.

When writing Pink Flamingos, I wanted to emphasize knowing when to lean on someone, even when you want to keep them at arm's length. Life can surprise you, especially with the people who stick around to witness it with you. As someone who has struggled with anxiety and has seen the repercussions of it, I know in my heart this is a story I need to tell. My hopes are to open up a discussion with the viewers on this topic and to establish a female voice in a male dominant industry. I can’t stress how delighted I am with the team I have assembled. It is because of their same passion and drive for this project, that I know we can produce a worthwhile film. Thank you again for your contribution, we appreciate your time and consideration. Your help sets the foundation for this film and gives life to this story!

We understand these are tough times and we appreciate you checking out our campaign. Here are a few other ways you can help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise! Just mentioning our project to your friends and family will help tremendously.
  • Check out the Indiegogo share tools. There are plenty of ways to share this campaign and with your help we know we can achieve our goal!

story:
Introduction

Hello! 

I am Matthew Quek, a Singaporean singer-songwriter, executive movie producer, actor, Special Education Needs (SEN) Counsellor and Educator.

I have invisible Special Education Needs (SEN) which were only diagnosed during my National Service after going through much trauma, isolation and discrimination throughout much of my school life.

 

Short Film Project: "The Prism"

“You have the ability to adjust the lens through which you view the world.” ― Jeffrey G. Duarte

We aim to produce a meaningful and impactful short film entitled "The Prism", and we appeal for your support to realise this project.

This film, which I am involved in on a strictly personal capacity, will be based on a first-person portrayal of the life of an individual with autism/ASD/Asperger's and multiple special needs living during the COVID-19 lockdown phase, featuring especially, the struggles his caregivers face in the midst of unemployment, retrenchment, discrimination and mental health challenges.

Although largely fictitious in nature, it will be based on real-life accounts of such individuals.

 

What We Need 

This film project has already been officially supported and granted partial funding by MCCY (Ministry of Culture, Community & Youth) via the OSF (Our Singapore Fund) and SG Enable. We are immensely thankful for their support and endorsement.

However, in order to realise this vision, we need to raise additional funds for the project.

We hope to produce and release this movie during the second half of 2021 as we would like to bring greater awareness to the difficult reality of those living with such challenges daily via the Purple Parade 2021 in October.

 

Achieving the Vision with YOUR Help

We hope to inspire children and youths with SEN to invest their efforts and time to produce and showcase their artistic works and areas of talent.

Our desire is to see children and youths with SEN meaningfully integrated into Singaporean society, whether at school, work or play.

Through this project and your kind financial support, we hope to be ambassadors for those who need a voice and have flown under the radar in our society for a long time.

This project is intended to be a springboard from which others may step up as fellow ambassadors for those who may face similar challenges, and feel isolated and discouraged in our society.

Together, we aim to play our part in a collective effort of ensuring that future generations of Singaporeans would be able to truly enjoy being immersed in a genuinely-inclusive nation. 

 

Additional Information

“It takes a village to raise a child”, it is often said, but it takes a lot more for those with special needs.

Nonetheless, with the right hearts of love, empathy, kindness, compassion and perseverance, the most daunting of odds can be overcome together.

Life can be meaningful and purposeful because of the right hearts, right people and right platforms working towards the same goal of genuine inclusivity.

This film and corresponding theme song could be used by various Special Education Organisations as a tool to enable special needs individuals to healthily integrate into school life, work life and other aspects of social interaction without an unhealthy fear of bullying, rejection and discrimination. This will complement the country’s efforts to rise above this crisis and galvanise one another for collective recovery and hope for the future.

This work will subtly highlight the recent initiatives of Skills Future, re-skilling and employment, in tandem with community togetherness in forging a social glue that will ensure that we, as a nation and society, arise from this crisis stronger, empathetic and much more resilient.

 

Past Works Featuring Individuals with SEN (Special Education Needs) 

  • “We Belong” (https://youtu.be/fhwQ0dmBgOA): Music Video featuring SEN individuals and how they are integral to our collective social fabric and moral compass (Dec 2020) – sponsored by the National Arts Council via the Digital Grant, in conjunction with the Singapore Kindness Movement.
  • "Unbroken: 不倒翁”  Short film based on my life’s story coping with lifelong invisible learning disabilities (Jun 2017) – co-sponsored by Touch Community services.

a) Trailer: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RQ5OgKYQ1iw
b) Music Video:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RQ5OgKYQ1iw

  • Recent song compositions on how we can emerge from the current crisis stronger and more united:

a) True Love that binds(https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IDbJA86OS3E)

b) Keep us Strong (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GWypyHwmNuU)

story:
Short Summary

Hi family, friends, and people here out of boredom and curiosity!

Some of you may know me from North Carolina, some of you from California, but all of you probably know that I've been living in LA for awhile now... rolling the dice on a chance to do what I love for a living. It's been quite the interesting journey so far, and yet, it's still just the beginning!

This summer, I'm finally embarking on making my first short film since my senior thesis in college. 'Without A Doubt' is a lighthearted comedy set in the early 2000's, and it's a project that means a lot to me. However, it takes a lot of blood, sweat, and tears to film something independently yet professionally, which I'll explain more below, but I could really use your help! 

My hope is that this film conveys the idea that young girls should not be afraid to take control of their own destiny and go after what they deserve... and also makes you laugh along the way! If this is a message/endeavor you can get behind, I would greatly appreciate your support. Any amount helps!

 

Allow me to introduce you to our CREW!

In the spirit of the film... here's the photos of the crew NOW & THEN. 

 

Delaney Lloyd

Writer/Director

 

Producer

Laurel Pierce

 

Director of Photography

Amber Steele

 

Kristen Batko

Production Designer

 

What We Need & What You Get

If you're not in the film industry, you may not know that making a short film (especially in LA) is quite the daunting challenge. You've got to find strong crew, talented actors, FEED them (at the bare minimum), rent expensive camera packages and lighting equipment, secure believable locations, buy ample set design, and so on. That's why the budgets on all your favorite movies are millions of dollars and the credits are SO long. 

We are but a humble indie short film, though, so while we don't need millions of dollars... the costs do add up. Here are some of the things we'll be putting the money towards:

- Renting a camera package, lighting equipment, and sound equipment

- Feeding our cast and crew healthy and filling meals who are volunteering their precious time

- Buying set dressing, props, and costumes to make the scene feel as real and accurate as possible

- Music license fees for 2000's specific songs

- Entry fees for film festivals around the country that allow the finished product to be seen and enjoyed on the big screen

Plus all of the little things speed bumps that cost money along the way!

 

Check out our shiny PERKS for what you'll get in return for your gracious contribution!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't spare any cash, we'd really appreciate you sharing this!

We're also on Instagram @WithoutADoubtFilm - give us a follow for more updates to come! We'll be revealing cast VERY soon :)

story:
Short Summary

ASYLUM is a character driven, self-acceptance drama. With a unique African perspective, it mirrors the best of intimate, nuanced coming out movies like “Call Me by Your Name” and “Blackbird”.

Director/Writer: Lionel Onyekwere

 Lionel Onyekwere is a Writer/Director based in Los Angeles, California. He hails from humble   beginnings in Nigeria, where he obtained his Bachelor’s degree in Law. 

 In his final year he directed and produced a Fashion show “#TFE2017”, where he sought to   showcase the works of aspiring designers; who were still in college, by putting them on the same runway with already prominent fashion brands in   the country.

 His endeavors led him to the US in pursuance of a career in film. He seeks to tell important,   necessary and beautiful stories highlighting the African experience.

Producer: Ajay Mohamed 

 Ajay started his career as an aspiring model and choreographer. To give wings to his dreams, he   moved to Mumbai and, within no time, his sheer determination and abilities fetched him a   significant place in Bollywood. In Bollywood, his talent got widely recognized and soon he was of various shows and got associated with one of the renowned production houses. But as they say, brilliant minds should not be confined in a secluded place rather they should be given more exposure to bring a revolution. Going by the saying, Ajay steered his wheel towards Los   Angeles and soon got various tags under his hat, namely Actor, Director and Producer. In his short span at Hollywood, Ajay has acted in various short films, has directed and produced various music videos, crossing over a million views, garnering applauds from round the world.

A social service enthusiast, Ajay has always been at forefront to bring positive changes in the world. While shaping his dreams, he has never shied away from engaging himself in social causes. He always tries to incorporate his vision in his work, his most recent music video as director, namely “OLORUN MAJE” was dedicated to the martyrs of the Leki Tollgate Massacre. A staunch supporter of women and children rights, he wishes to sensitize the world about the same. To realize this cause, he even started an online movement called “Parda” which offers platform to the unheard voices and share their agonies with the world.

 

Co-producer: Ebenezer Alasi

 Ebenezer Alasi is a Los Angeles based Actor of Nigerian descent. Having received a Bachelor’s   Degree in Electrical Engineering from the University of Ilorin, he worked in the Finance   sector as an Investment Banker for about 5 years.

 Ebenezer enrolled at the New York Film Academy in Los Angeles, where he received a certification in Acting for Film. Since graduating, he has starred in numerous short films, TV shows, Commercials and Theatre productions. 

 His goal is to tell stories that are impactful and inspiring. Both on-screen and behind the scenes.

What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise $15000 for the whole production cost including marketing and post production.

Our goal for this project is to reach out to the worldwide audience, inspire them, and change their lives.

We'll be sending this movie to different film festivals all around the globe.

By being part of this inspiring project, you'll touch and change many lives in Nigeria and other countries where the same sex relationship is illegal.

We have decided to give onscreen credits to every backer plus if there is someone who doesn't want to get credit on the screen, they'll get the free tickets for screening.

The Impact

WHY THIS FILM?

NECESSITY; A necessity for a much-needed conversation, one which Nigeria has swept under the rug for too long. Many have lost their lives, more have shrunk themselves in every way that matters, some perpetuate their lives based on foundations of lies, suffering in silence, self-hatred, and unhappy homes, yet we still neglect a conversation about what it is to be queer and African.

Risks & Challenges

By making this project we are putting our lives in danger, because this project can or will hurt some people's old school sentiments. They'll definitely try to create obstacles in every phase of making of this movie.
But we are ready to take this challenge and we want you to join us in this and be our strength.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Spread words about our project and this campaign. 

Social media is the biggest platform to influence mass audience and you all can help us in doing that.

Many have lost their lives, more have shrunk themselves in every way that matters, some perpetuate their lives based on foundations of lies, suffering in silence, self-hatred, and unhappy homes, yet we still neglect a conversation about what it is to be queer and African.Risks & ChallengesBy making this project we are putting our lives in danger, because this project can or will hurt some people's old school sentiments. They'll definitely try to create obstacles in every phase of making of this movie.But we are ready to take this challenge and we want you to join us in this and be our strength.Other Ways You Can HelpSome people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:Spread words about our project and this campaign. Social media is the biggest platform to influence mass audience and you all can help us in doing that.

story:
Short Summary

This story is inspired by a true event that happened in L.A. Bully has always been a controversial topic in society. During the creation of this film, the director, Sara found that many young adults have encountered similar violent experience.  

A generation that is highly influenced by social media. We tend to neglect other's feeling but ours.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Your contribution to this short film is a big portion of making it happens: from equipment renting to production design, transportation costs and food for the crew and the cast. 

Your contribution will also to help with submitting the film to film festivals.

Depends on donation, we will include your name or your company at the end of the film. Also, you will be receiving a finished version of our film, 18 along with a signed poster. If you cannot donate, we totally understand. We wish you can spread the word around about it! 

Many thanks!

 

Meet Our Team

Sara Yin /Director, Co-Producer

Sara Yin is a Senior in Film & Video major at Drexel University. She has an interest in every aspect of filmmaking. She has been working on a lot of film sets, and she found her greatest interest in directing. She has directed several films and was the winner as the best student film in Mountain Film Festival in 2017. She is greatly looking forward to making the film as the director and the screenwriter. 

Li Jing/ Co-Producer

Jing Li is an international student who is a Film & Video major with an interest in producing films. She has been working on professional film and TV sets in China and in a number of roles. She has produced, and assistant directed several short films and projects at Drexel University, and she looks forward to doing so with the group. 

Leyla Aytaman/ Assistant Director

Leyla is a senior film major at Drexel University. While she has a love for cameras and producing, she has a strong passion for assistant directing and has assistant directed a number of short films. She looks forward to working with the wonderful crew of "18" and is excited to help bring this film to life.

Laurence Frail/ Director of Photography

Laurence is a Film & Video major with strong experience in operating cameras. His skill helped him to get involved in many commercials and films, collaborated with Nike, Honda and Street Dreams Magazine. He also has a great experience with editing, and it helped him to visualize frames creatively when he is on camera. He operated the camera for a lot of campus events and worked in fast-paced environments. His work was accepted into the “Under The Underground” Film Festival in Boston in 2017. He is excited to work on “18” and bring his creativity to the story. 

Laurel Gabel/ Art Director

Laurel Gabel is a senior film & video student with a minor in Television Production and Media Management. She has been working on film sets since before her time at Drexel, including PA jobs as a food stylist for magazine photoshoots, event assistance for concerts, fashion shows, and product launches. She has always had an interest in art direction and production design and is looking forward to using her creative skills to dress and decorate for this film!

Colin Perry/ Sound Mixer

Colin Perry found a passion for sound throughout his career at Drexel University. He realizes the importance of producing sound. His experiences on sets helped him to develop strength in sound production. He worked on many films sets as a sound mixer, and he brings the story to life through sound.

story:
Together, we are passionate film students looking to create a film that will be of interest to viewers of the short and indie film arts. As lovely students in the production world, we are looking to break the boundaries of cliche student films and create a story and visual novel that is appealing to the general viewer. 

One fateful day, 16 year old Harrison goes to the mailbox in the forest he’s been visiting and finds a letter from his mysterious ‘friend’ who claims to be writing to him from the future. The letters detail specific moments that will only happen to Harrison, but this time it details a prediction about his mother. It is up to Harrison to decide whether he is able to rewrite the future or not. Here are some images for the visual aesthetic of the story: 

 

Harrison 16

A playful and carefree kid, Harrison's love for creative writing helps him cope with living in a small town with few kids his age. His sense of imagination keeps him a young soul, however his naïvety hinders him from making rational decisions. His impulsiveness derives from the loss of his father, which also contributes to his difficulties showing affection for his Mom.

Vivian (Mom) 40

A single mom, Vivian isn't afraid to show her only son some tough love. She struggles managing between her job as a nurse and her obligations as a mother. After her husband abandoned her, she moved to a small town bordering a dense forest to escape from her harsh reality. The only part of her life that gives her meaning is her son and she will do anything to make sure that he is safe.

We are CSULB students, freelance filmmakers, and overall, lovely people. 

MAXIM CARADONNA Director

Maxim Caradonna is a student at CSULB studying Directing and Producing. Originally from San Diego, he found his passion for filmmaking in high school and began learning through photography. After many years of volunteering at film festivals and creating content for local businesses, he decided to move to Los Angeles to find more opportunities and surround himself with likeminded people. Once he graduates university he plans to start his own production company and contribute to positive Asian-American representation in Hollywood.

 

RUDY SOLIDARIOS Assistant Director 

Rudy Solidarios is a student at CSULB and freelance editor and grip in narrative, promotional, and music video content. Originally from the Mojave Desert, she is now based in and around Los Angeles doing work and obtaining experience when she can. She has work with Blizzard Entertainment, AT&T, DreamworksTV, and many miscellaneous commercials. Her goal is to eventually own her own production company and create a positive impact in the film industry. When she is not dedicating her time to filmmaking, Rudy likes to spend her time behind an instrument or exploring the outdoors. 

 

EDGAR FARIAS Producer

Edgar is an aspiring film producer that knows that any production is possible with the right game plan! He has worked on various on set productions that range from graduate films, commercials, live broadcasts, web-series, and even promotional photoshoots. Edgar has worked with organizations such as Blizzard Entertainment, AT&T, Royal Enfield, The American Film Institute, and AwesomenessTV - to name a few. Edgar ultimately wants to work in the ever-changing entertainment industry and helm quality film productions that compliment today’s streaming age. In his personal life, Edgar enjoys going to live concerts and staying current on the latest music trends. He also has a personal goal of traveling somewhere outside the U.S. at least once a year.

 

RYAN JABOLA Director of Photography

Ryan Jabola is currently studying cinematography at CSULB, where he hopes to learn from his peers, experiment, and exercise his creative instincts in filmmaking. He moved from Modesto to Los Angeles to surround himself with one of many cultures that finds a purpose in producing meaningful narrative content. Ryan’s purpose in cinema is to capture content that evokes profound emotions among a wide variety of audiences. Outside of film, Ryan enjoys learning about music production, and works as a personal trainer at the CSULB Student Recreation and Wellness center.

 

3K covers the costs of actors, location, housing, and of course, food. Our location is projected to be about 2 hours away from our home location and we have to transfer about 20 of our crew, so we would like to cover the costs of transportation in addition to the housing for our crew and cast. Below, you will find the budget breakdown of the film:

We are a group of ambitious students that can combine our experiences and creative energy to create quailty films. But, we can't step outside of our box without the right funds, unfortunately. We have big minds and big imaginations and we want to create films that introduce interesting ideas and visual aesthetic. In order to meet our creative goals, we needed to find a way to fund our passions and projects. That's where you come in. We are not just asking for your donations, but your support. We hope we can capture your attention and your support along the way!

If you don't have the money to donate, well hey, thank you for taking time out of your day to read about our project! Any interest to learn about our film is care enough in our eyes and we appreciate you for that. You could help us even MORE by sharing our campaign on social media! Also by sharing it with your family, friends, coworkers, pets, enemies...anyone! 

If you are someone or know somebody who would be interested in donating in any other way (I.E. housing, food, equipment, love), then please feel free to contact us at: dearharrisonfilm@gmail.com

We truly thank you from the bottom of our hearts for your time and care. Raising money from strangers isn't easy, but we hope we sealed your support in the process. We are looking forward to sharing our story with you all.

story:
How we came to this project.

Writer/Director Jeff Verlanic is passionate about his family's roots in rural Montana and the often overlooked queer communities of the American west. For the last five years he has been pursuing an MFA with New York University's Tisch School of the Arts and this project is his thesis - the culmination of years spent studying with professors like Spike Lee, Eliza Hittman, Todd Solondz, and numerous others. 

While working at 57th Street Books on the South Side of Chicago to support his work as an improviser at Second City and improvOlympic, Jeff came across Mary MacLane's memoirs and couldn't believe they hadn't been adapted. The strength of her voice and the unbelievable story of a radical woman living in rural Montana at the end of the 19th century stuck with him. Ten years later, he is finally realizing the dream of turning this brilliant text into a film.

How far along is the film?

We have shot 20 rolls of 16mm film and are eager to start editing - supporting this project means bringing it into existence. It may be in the can but we still have so much left to do. Post production is really when a movie comes to life: processing with Fotokem in Los Angeles, editing, and distributing are all expensive steps ahead and every donation helps to finish and release this beautiful project. This film is urgent - it tells the story of a resilient woman trapped within her experiences of internalized sexism. The ruins of the ghost town reflect her isolation. Trapped inside of herself she turns to her writing but cannot escape the torments of sexism and homophobia.

NYU generously provides financial support for thesis work but their allotment barely covers even the most basic production costs. The cast and crew have all worked for well below their normal rates out of love for this project. Everyone involved can't wait to share the short with the world, however, finishing a film is expensive - we need money to pay our composer, for sound editing, music recording, film processing, color-grading, festival submissions, musicians etc...

We are focused on the ways in which this project bridges the gap between Montana and New York City. Our perks reflect the important role played by each of these communities.

 

Why is this important?

Trust Your Visions

Women of the 19th century weren't allowed to have strong opinions, let alone to write radical memoirs challenging the status quo, or leave the house without a corset, but Mary stood against the conservative culture surrounding her only to find her best-selling book banned. We are still not as far along in the fight for equity surrounding gender and sexual orientation as we should be but our team believes stories like this help to inspire as the fight for equality and freedom of expression continues.

The queer movement has the ability to reshape the world in powerful ways.  'I Await the Devil's Coming' is a further exploration of the blending of surrealist fantasia and historical activism. After screening at festivals around the US with previous projects this creative team believes 'I Await the Devil's Coming' has a more global reach, as we finish the film our goal is to have a festival run all over the world and we can't wait to have you get more involved. 

The Rest of the Team

Cast

Rosa Gilmore has delivered an incredible performance as Mary MacLane. After completing her studies with NYU's prestigious graduate acting program, can be seen on shows including 'Handmaid's Tale', 'Elementary', and 'The Expanse'. Rosa has also worked in theatre productions across New York City including Shakespeare in the Park's all-female 'Taming of the Shrew'. 

Her love interest Katherine - the mysterious anemone lady - is played by Katie Kohler. Originally from Montana,  Katie is based in Austin, TX where she works with companies including Austin Playhouse, Hyde Park Theatre, and with The Paramount Theatre’s Literacy To Life program. 

Jeff Medley has been acting all over Missoula, MT for more than a decade and has appeared in films long and short including 'Lester Leaps In', 'The Ballad of Lefty Brown', and 'Subterranea'. In 'I Await the Devil's Coming' he plays Napoleon Bonaparte, Father Cromwell, and Lucifer. 

And introducing Amelia Paulette Schaffnit as young Mary! Amelia is a five-year-old from
Missoula and this is her very first film (and her first time to Bannack)!

Crew

Award-winning cinematographer Alejandro Miyashiro has shot projects which have screened at festivals all over the world including the Cannes Film Festival, OutFest, and more. His collaboration with Jeff began early in their time at NYU,  'I Await The Devil's Coming' will be their third film as a team.

Producer Kate Stahl recently graduated from the MFA/MBA dual degree program at NYU and is currently program manager at the Production Lab. She has produced award winning shorts including 'Alex and the Handyman', 'The Babysitter', and Jeff's 'Queer Cruising Double Feature: gaysemiotics & Ave Maria'. 

Assistant director Daliso Leslie is a narrative and documentary filmmaker. The recipient of the Spike Lee Film Production Grant Daliso has produced work for Common Justice, The Global Fund for Women, and the Banlieue Rhythm Factory in Dakar, Senegal. It is his second time collaborating with Jeff and Alejandro together.

Camera team Cheryl Wong and Farida Zahran are both studying film at Tisch and have each screened their own directorial works at festivals including SXSW.

Costume designer Aaron Crosby graduated from NYU Tisch School of the Arts in 2018 with an MFA in Design for Stage & Film. He is extremely passionate about corsets.

Makeup artist Ashley Di Sarro has worked on numerous sets and has a focus on health and wellness as part of her process. 

Tessla Hastings has art directed numerous shorts and features including 'Mickey and the Bear', 'Buster's Mal Heart', 'The Ballad of Lefty Brown', 'Lester Leaps In', and numerous others. 

Jay Warrior is a highly accomplished gaffer and cinematographer. He has worked on countless NYU Tisch sets around the world.

Sound mixer Raines Plambeck is also about to complete her studies at NYU Tisch grad film. After working in development and on set for Maven productions Raines has been writing and directing while also studying sound closely. Her thesis script was chosen for the Production Lab Development Studio

Eric Mosely has worked on films all over Montana as a grip and cinematographer. He can also provide you with stunning portraits for your social media/romantic apps.

Unit production manager Lily Frandsen (also known as our set momma) studied art history in Paris but quickly realized the dutch masters had nothing on a Montana sunset and promptly returned to her home state where she continues to support the arts in every way possible. She kept us safe, warm, and fed for the duration of the shoot. 

Boom operator Danny Haniszewski is a visual artist, poet, musician, and queer farmer who grew up down the street from the director. His art is amazing and a zine of his poems is a part of the 'Montana Author Bundle'. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share our campaign, point us towards grants, and help us tell Mary's story. We think, especially in this political moment, the world needs to hear the story of a brave woman who refused to accept the oppressive expectations of her time. If you are an artist or business owner please get in touch with us about the possibility of donating goods and services to our campaign. Thank you.

Eric Mosely has worked on films all over Montana as a grip and cinematographer. He can also provide you with stunning portraits for your social media/romantic apps.

Unit production manager Lily Frandsen (also known as our set momma) studied art history in Paris but quickly realized the dutch masters had nothing on a Montana sunset and promptly returned to her home state where she continues to support the arts in every way possible. She kept us safe, warm, and fed for the duration of the shoot. 

Boom operator Danny Haniszewski is a visual artist, poet, musician, and queer farmer who grew up down the street from the director. His art is amazing and a zine of his poems is a part of the 'Montana Author Bundle'. 
 


Other Ways You Can Help
Please share our campaign, point us towards grants, and help us tell Mary's story. We think, especially in this political moment, the world needs to hear the story of a brave woman who refused to accept the oppressive expectations of her time. If you are an artist or business owner please get in touch with us about the possibility of donating goods and services to our campaign. Thank you.

story:
Time is Running Out

The plunge to extinction for Chinook salmon and Southern Resident orcas speeds up, nipping at the heels of the plodding, clumsy pace of political change in the Pacific Northwest, where dams and hydropower are king.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal of $12,000 will allow for wide reaching, impactful distribution and marketing of Dammed to Extinction. The only way to save the Southern Resident orcas and the salmon on which they rely is to spread the word – to tell the story of these suffering species. 

Of course, saving orcas and Chinook is its own reward, but we want to share our appreciation of your efforts, so we've got copies of film writer Steven Hawley's Recovering a Lost River and some really dope t-shirts to say "Thank You," to contributors like you.

The Impact

Without help from folks like you, the Southern Residents and the Chinook salmon will soon perish. That means that your investment in Dammed to Extinction is an investment in ensuring a future for these doomed Pacific Northwest icons. Please save the orcas and the Chinook before it's too late.

Other Ways You Can Help

Lobby your congressperson. Tell you friends. Call Washington Governor Inslee's office. 

In short, spread the word far and wide that a majestic species of salmon and a powerful, inspirational pod of orcas is doomed if we do not remove the lower four Snake River dams and restore their natural habitats.

story:
Short Summary

Hello! We are Jemima and Jesimiel Damina, co-founders of a media company called Neptune3 Studios. Our official outlet is our YouTube Channel, and we post videos weekly. Growing up in the small town of Uyo, Nigeria, film has always been a combined joy of ours. We are both passionate about telling stories our generation can relate to and enjoy through the various media available to us.  After graduation, we returned to Nigeria and decided to just start something, sort of get our feet wet in Nigerian filmmaking. That something eventually became the first episode of our ongoing web series, Best Friends in the World, a teen-centred miniseries about friendship, family and of course, young love. 

This campaign is so important to us because part of our vision is to impact on the minds of young people with readily available wholesome content that surrounds them with positivity and joy. With our first two episodes already over a million views each and others quickly catching up, we are convinced that we are achieving our goal.

We would like to conclude the series on a high note, leaving it short and sweet, but to do that we need your support. This whole time we've been self-funded and we're not able to complete our last 8 episodes as comfortably as we would like, improving the speed and quality that we have had. Your donation would go a long way to helping us attain a satisfying ending to the series, pay our cast and crew (who are 98% university students and have worked this whole time despite their school schedules and personal lives without pay).

If we surpass our goal, we are all ready to come back for a Best Friends in the World movie with the original cast and an exciting new adventure. The movie will be uploaded to YouTube and free for you to view on our channel.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $20,000. Making films in an unstandardized country like Nigeria costs twice as much money and energy as anywhere else. From renting equipment to transportation, hotels, feeding, makeup/wardrobe, locations, electricity (no constant power supply, so we run a generator 90% of the time), to the cast and crew, each episode is time-consuming, energy-sapping, money-sucking and yet highly rewarding thanks to the dedication of our fans. 

If we're unable to reach our goal, we will split what we get between shooting as much as we can and compensating our amazing cast/crew for their time and dedication. If you've enjoyed these characters and their stories, please donate what you can do give them their happy ending.

The Impact

If you're here and you're a fan of Best Friends in the World, then we know you've taken at least one thing away from our episodes. We would like you to have closure on the series and the characters involved. No amount is too small to help us reach the finish line.

We already have 12 episodes (2 seasons) under our belt. We would like for you to enjoy the 3rd and final one by giving you the best stories, quality and happy cast members. 

Risks & Challenges

Sometimes due to weather, illnesses, faulty equipment, or just life in general, we are not able to meet our weekly uploads and you've been there with us through all of that. Sometimes we have literally had to do the impossible to get the episodes to you on time because we made a commitment to you and we intend to keep it. We hope you stick with us-- we're almost there! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Hey, we get it. Sometimes it's bad timing and you'd really like to help but you can't. Still, you can help us by spreading the word about this campaign! Share using the Indiegogo share tools to get the word out-- someone you share to might be able to put in some money, and we appreciate every single effort.

Thank you so much for your donation. We look forward to a smooth-sailing final term!
